page.title: Abbreviations for Classical authors and texts

revision.comment: Mention DGE as an alternative to LSJ
revision.text:
'''Abbreviations for Classical authors and texts''' are abbreviations used to refer to ancient authors and their works that are used in academic publications in the field of [[Classics]] ([[Latin]] and [[Ancient Greek]] language, literature, history, [[classical archaeology|archaeology]]). Two systems are in common use, based on the abbreviations lists of standard reference works:
* The [[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://classics.oxfordre.com/staticfiles/images/ORECLA/OCD.ABBREVIATIONS.pdf |title=OCD Abbreviations |website=classics.oxfordre.com |format=PDF}}</ref> (''OCD''), which covers both Greek and Latin authors and texts. * [[Liddell & Scott]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://stephanus.tlg.uci.edu/lsj/01-authors_and_works.html | title=Authors and Works}}</ref> (LSJ) (or [[Diccionario Griego-Español]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dge.cchs.csic.es/lst/2lst-int.htm | title=DGE: Bibliographical Lists}} ''DGE'' uses the same abbreviations as LSJ, but is more up to date and covers a much larger selection of texts (“all Greek writers and documentary texts from Mycenaean times until the end of the antiquity”).</ref> [''DGE'']) for Greek authors and texts, combined with either the [[Thesaurus Linguae Latinae]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thesaurus.badw.de/hilfsmittel-fuer-benutzer/index.html | title=Index: Thesaurus linguae Latinae}}</ref> (''ThLL'') or the [[Oxford Latin Dictionary]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oxfordscholarlyeditions.com/page/abbreviations | title=Abbreviations - Oxford Scholarly Editions}}</ref> (''OLD'') for Latin authors and texts.
The two systems overlap substantially: [[Homer]] and [[Plato]], for instance, are "Hom." and "Pl." in both the ''OCD'' and LSJ; [[Cicero]] and [[Horace]] are "Cic." and "Hor." in the ''OCD'', the ''ThLL'', and the ''OLD''. Occasionally, however, abbreviations in LSJ are shorter than in the ''OCD'': for instance, [[Aeschylus]] and [[Euripides]] are "A." and "E." in LSJ, "Aesch." and "Eur." in the ''OCD''. As a consequence, abbreviations in the ''OCD'' can be clearer than those in LSJ. However, the ''OCD'' has fewer abbreviations for authors and texts than LSJ and the ''OLD'' or ''ThLL'' combined, so publications dealing with minor authors and texts not included in the ''OCD'' often have to resort to the other, fuller system.
Both for Greek and for Latin texts, in both the systems referred to above, abbreviations are conventionally based on the Latin name of the author and title of the work. For instance, [[Aristophanes]]' ''[[The Frogs|Frogs]]'' is abbreviated ''Ra.'' or ''Ran.'' (from ''Ranae'') and [[Horace]]'s ''[[Odes (Horace)|Odes]]'' are abbreviated ''Carm.'' (from ''Carmina''). This is due to the former status of Latin as the language of scholarly communication in the discipline as well as to the usefulness of having a set of references that is valid across present-day national and linguistic boundaries.
When a work is falsely attributed to an author by ancient sources, his abbreviated name is often put between square brackets: for instance, the ''[[Shield of Heracles]]'' falsely attributed to [[Hesiod]] is abbreviated as [Hes.] ''Sc.'' (from ''Scutum''). An alternative is "Pseudo-" (abbreviated "Ps.") attached to the purported author's name, such as the anonymous "Pseudo-Longinus" who authored the treatise ''[[On the Sublime]]''.
Fragments and certain kinds of texts, such as [[dictionary|lexica]] and [[scholia]], are generally referenced with the surname(s) of the editor(s) of the edition used, so as to disambiguate it from other editions of the same text which may have different numbering systems. The surname(s) can be cited entire or abbreviated: for instance, [[Bruno Snell|Snell]]-[[Herwig Maehler|Maehler]] or Sn.-M. for the fragments of Pindar.
As well as authors' names and the titles of works, Classical publications often use abbreviations for other items that are relevant to Classical antiquity. These also tend to come in standardised form:
* For [[papyrus|papyri]] and similar materials such as [[ostracon|ostraca]], the ''Checklist of Editions of Greek, Latin, Demotic and Coptic Papyri, Ostraka and Tablets''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://papyri.info/docs/checklist | title=Papyri.info}}</ref>. * For [[epigraphy|inscriptions]], the abbreviations list of the ''[[Supplementum Epigraphicum Graecum]]'' (''SEG'')<ref>https://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/supplementum-epigraphicum-graecum/abbreviations-aabbr (paywalled)</ref>. * For [[academic journals|journals]], the abbreviations list of the ''[[L'Année Philologique|Année Philologique]]''<ref>Available on the [https://about.brepolis.net/lannee-philologique-aph/ ''Année Philologique'' website]. The most recent list (as of 25 November 2018) is: https://aboutbrepolis.files.wordpress.com/2018/09/aph_abbrc3a9viations.pdf.</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Academic publishing]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum | name = Bahrain National Museum | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Bahrain National Museum Exterior.jpg | imagesize = 500 | caption = Bahrain National Museum | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | map_size = | coordinates = | established = 1988 | dissolved = | location = [[Manama]], [[Bahrain]] | type = [[Public]] | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = [http://www.bahraintourism.com/default.asp?action=article&id=151 Government site] }}
The '''Bahrain National Museum''' ({{lang-ar|متحف البحرين الوطني}}, also referred to as '''National Museum of Bahrain''') is the largest and one of the oldest public [[museum]]s in [[Bahrain]]. It is constructed near the King Faisal Highway in [[Manama]] and opened in December 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=The National Museum of Bahrain |url=http://archnet.org/library/pubdownloader/pdf/9069/doc/DPC1383.PDF |work=ArchNet |accessdate=18 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120064247/http://archnet.org/library/pubdownloader/pdf/9069/doc/DPC1383.PDF |archivedate=20 November 2008 |df= }}</ref> The [[United States dollar|US$]]30 million museum complex covers 27,800 sq meters and consists of two buildings. The [[National Theatre of Bahrain]] lies next to the museum.
==Exhibitions==
The museum possess a rich collection of [[Bahrain]]'s ancient [[Archaeology|archaeological]] [[artifact (archaeology)|artifact]]s acquired since 1988, and covers nearly 5000 years of [[History of Bahrain|Bahrain's history]]. The complex includes three halls devoted to archaeology and the ancient civilisation of the [[Dilmun]], while two other halls depict the [[Culture of Bahrain|culture]] and lifestyle of Bahrain's recent pre-industrial past. A notable exhibit is the [[Durand Stone]], a long black [[basalt]] sculpture dating back to the [[Babylonia]]n era.
In 1993, a further hall was opened, the [[Natural History]] Hall, focusing on the [[Bahrain#Biodiversity|natural environment]] of Bahrain. This hall features specimens of Bahrain's [[flora]] and [[fauna]]. Among the exhibits in the ancient history section is an actual [[Dilmun Burial Mounds|burial mound]] which was transported from its site in the desert and reassembled in the museum. Another feature is a [[Tableau vivant|tableau]] which depicts a scene from the [[Epic of Gilgamesh]] (in which reference to Bahrain is made as the paradise of [[Dilmun]]).
Old [[Quran]]ic manuscripts, notes on [[astronomy]] and historical documents and letters are exhibited in the ''Documents and Manuscripts Hall''. The building was designed by [[KHR Arkitekter]] of Denmark.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khr.dk/#/142128/ |title=Kronologisk |publisher=KHR Arkitekter |accessdate=17 November 2009}}</ref>
The building contains the original nine major galleries, educational hall, [[gift shop]] and a [[cafeteria]], in addition to administrative offices, laboratories and warehouses for the Conservation of holdings and parking.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bahrain Museum |url=http://bahraindiscovery.com/bahrain_museum.html |accessdate=18 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120005035/http://bahraindiscovery.com/bahrain_museum.html |archivedate=20 November 2012 |df= }}</ref>
{{wide image|Bahrain museum panorama.jpg|1100px|Panorama of the Hall of Graves exhibit|centre}}
==Gallery== <gallery> File:1932 Buick Bahrain Museum.JPG|A restored 1932 [[Buick]] given to [[Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa]] by the American government. Donated to the Museum in 1992. File:Bahrainnationalmuseum.JPG|The museum's exterior. File:Assyrian Clay Coffin, 6th century BC .JPG|[[Assyria]]n [[Clay]] [[Coffin]], dating from the 6th century BC. File:Early burial mound , moved to Bahrain museum.JPG|Early [[burial mound]], originally in [[Hamad Town]], moved to the museum. File:Oil lamps in museum Bahrain A256.jpg| [[Oil lamp]]s on exhibit File:Seals from Dilmun A112.JPG|Seals from early Dilmun period (2000-1800 B.C.). File:Pearl diver sculpture in Bahrain National Museum.jpg| [[Pearl diving]] sculpture outside the museum. </gallery>

revision.comment: Include reference to UN Solutions Summit award
revision.text:
'''BeeLine Reader''' is a software system which adds color gradients to digital text to improve reading ability and focus. The text at the end of each line is colored the same as the beginning of the next, so the color of the text acts as a flagpost that directs the reader's eyes through the text more easily. In each line, the color of the text transitions from one color to another, with each character being slightly different than the preceding and following characters.
The system is available as an extension in [[Google Chrome]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/beeline-reader/ifjafammaookpiajfbedmacfldaiamgg?hl=en|title=BeeLine Reader|website=chrome.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> and [[Firefox|Mozilla Firefox]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/beelinereader/|title=BeeLine Reader – Add-ons for Firefox|website=addons.mozilla.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>, as a PDF viewer<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/beeline-reader-pdf-viewer/pmeknoingfjncbdhempgnkdgojickcko/overview|title=BeeLine Reader PDF Viewer|website=chrome.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>, and as an iOS app<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/beeline-reader/id938026867?mt=8|title=BeeLine Reader|website=App Store|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>.<ref name="atlantic">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/05/a-better-way-to-read/482127/ |title=A Better Way to Read—in Color |last=Hamblin |first=James |work=The Atlantic |access-date=2018-05-12 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="mind">{{Cite journal |last=Schneps |first=Matthew |date=2015-01-01 |title=Using Technology to Break the Speed Barrier of Reading |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/286935964_Using_Technology_to_Break_the_Speed_Barrier_of_Reading |journal=Scientific American MIND}}</ref><ref name="cc">{{Cite journal |last=Rodrigue |first=Tanya K. |date=2017-12-01 |title=The Digital Reader, The Alphabetic Writer, and The Space Between: A Study in Digital Reading and Source-Based Writing |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S8755461516301062 |journal=Computers and Composition |language=en |volume=46 |pages=4–20 |doi=10.1016/j.compcom.2017.09.005 |issn=8755-4615}}</ref> These tools are mainly designed for use with web-based text, but can also be used to read Amazon Kindle books on iPad and via browser extension. The tools suppresses colors which already exist in text, such as the blue and red links in Wikipedia. Links are instead underlined. The BeeLine Reader tools have a freemium model, with some functionality available at no cost, but other functionality requiring payment<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" />.
The company's website lets readers compare their speed with and without the BeeLine colors.<ref name="chal">{{Cite web |url=http://www.beelinereader.com/challenge |title=BeeLine Reader :: Reading Challenge |last=Lum |first=Nick |website=www.beelinereader.com |language=en |access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> The system has won awards from the United Nations Solutions Summit, Stanford University and The Tech Museum of Innovation,<ref name="rif">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rif.org/beeline|title=Literacy Central & BeeLine Reader|last=|first=|date=|website=RIF.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> and has been reviewed by educators.<ref name="edsurge">{{Cite web |url= https://www.edsurge.com/product-reviews/beeline-reader |title=BeeLine Reader - Product Reviews - EdSurge |date=2015-12-01 |website=EdSurge |language=en-US |access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref>
== Adoption == BeeLine Reader's technology is patented<ref>{{Cite patent|title=Indicators of text continuity|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US9026907B2/en|country=US|number=9026907B2|inventor=Nicholas Lum|issue-date=2011-01-27|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> and has been adopted by the literacy nonprofit [[Reading Is Fundamental]] and the accessibility nonprofit [[Bookshare|Bookshare.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bookshareblog.wpengine.com/2016/09/beeline-reader-adds-color-to-bookshare/|title=BeeLine Reader Adds Color to Bookshare - Bookshare Blog|date=2016-09-30|work=Bookshare Blog|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref> [[California]] has bought a state-wide license for its libraries.<ref name="califa">{{Cite web|url=http://www.califa.org/beeline|title=BeeLine Reader {{!}} Califa|website=www.califa.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref>
== Efficacy == The company claims that independent testing has shown that its technology increases reading fluency and reading comprehension.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dropbox.com/s/vrsxf20jx2wp71g/BeeLine%20Research%20Summary.pdf?dl=0|title=BeeLine Research Summary.pdf|website=Dropbox|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> It also claims that BeeLine Reader has been shown to be effective as an assistive technology for special education students, in a study done by [[Bookshare]].<ref name=":4" /> A pilot study done by CNET showed that readers using BeeLine Reader on CNET stories read nearly 50 percent further into articles than readers using conventional text.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/05/a-better-way-to-read/482127/|title=A Better Way to Read—in Color|last=Hamblin|first=James|date=2016-05-11|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Data Privacy == The Privacy Policy says that the tools do not gather individual-level usage information. They do gather anonymous, aggregated information on what websites the tools are used to read on. The Privacy Policy provides instructions on how to defeat such collection, which is done via Google Analytics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.beelinereader.com/policy|title=BeeLine Reader: making reading on-screen easier and faster.|last=Lum|first=Nick|website=www.beelinereader.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Reading (process)]] [[Category:Google Chrome extensions]] [[Category:Software add-ons]] [[Category:Companies' terms of service]]

{{Advert|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox website |name = Bloc |logo = Bloc-logo-rectangle-grey.jpg |logo_size = 200px |company_type = |foundation = {{start date and age|2012|2|9}} |founder = Roshan Choxi, Dave Paola |location_city = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] |location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] |locations = |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = |industry = [[Internet industry|Internet]] |products = |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |owner = |num_employees = 11 - 50 |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |url = {{URL|https://www.bloc.io/}} |ipv6 = |website_type = |advertising = |num_users = |language = English |registration = |launch_date = |current_status = Active |commercial = Yes
}}
'''Bloc '''is an online interactive platform that offers a variety of online [[Coding Bootcamp|coding bootcamps]] in several areas including [[web development]], [[Mobile application development|mobile development]], and [[design]].
It also adopted the apprenticeship model where students are paired with an experienced mentor who provides support and guidance throughout the curriculum using [[Skype]].
== History == Bloc was founded in February 2012 by Roshan Choxi and Dave Paola.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc|url = https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/bloc-2|website = www.crunchbase.com|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> They met at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] in 2008, before moving to [[San Francisco]] where the company is currently headquartered. Subsequently, Paola and Choxi began tutoring students over Skype in 2012, then later introduced Bloc at the Launch Festival in San Francisco.<ref>{{Cite web|title = S.F. startup Bloc offers a new way to learn coding online|url = http://www.sfgate.com/technology/article/S-F-startup-Bloc-offers-a-new-way-to-learn-5109574.php|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> The company raised $250,000 in [[Seed money|seed funding]] in May 2012, $2 million in another seed funding in December 2013<ref>{{Cite web|title = Online Code School Bloc Raises $2 Million For Its Web Development "Apprenticeship" Program|url = https://techcrunch.com/2013/12/05/online-code-school-bloc-raises-2-million-for-its-web-development-apprenticeship-program/|accessdate = 2015-04-14|first = Sarah|last = Perez}}</ref> and $6 million in [[Series A round|Series A]] funding in November 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc Raises $6 Million Series A Round Led by Shasta Ventures|url = http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/bloc-raises-6-million-series-a-round-led-by-shasta-ventures-1969387.htm|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> The latest round of funding was Harrison Metal with First Round Capital.
In 2017 Bloc had 96 people enrol in their User experience design course of which 14 completed.
In April 2018, Bloc was acquired by online bootcamp Thinkful for an undisclosed sum. Officials at Thinkful said Bloc was not profitable and “almost breaking even” at the time the deal closed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2018-04-10-online-coding-bootcamp-thinkful-acquires-leading-competitor-bloc|title=Online Coding Bootcamp Thinkful Acquires Leading Competitor, Bloc - EdSurge News|date=2018-04-10|work=EdSurge|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Courses == Bloc has a total of 5 courses, and they are separated into 2 phases, foundation and building real projects phase. In the last 2 weeks of the courses, students and their mentors will work on a capstone project of their choice. All courses cost $5,000.
=== Rails Web Development === In the Foundation Phase, students will design, build, and ship their own version of web app. Mentors will guide students on how to use [[HTML]], [[Cascading Style Sheets|CSS]], [[JavaScript]], [[jQuery]], [[Ruby on Rails]], and [[SQL]] to build the app.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} The World's Largest Online Web Development Bootcamp|url = https://www.bloc.io/web-development-bootcamp|website = Bloc|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> In the Building Real Projects Phase, students will build web apps including versions of [[Wikipedia]], [[Google Analytics]] and [[Digg]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} The World's Largest Online Web Development Bootcamp|url = https://www.bloc.io/web-development-bootcamp|website = Bloc|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref>
=== Frontend Web Development === In the Foundation Phase, students will learn the foundation of frontend development by building a clone of [[Rdio]], a streaming music service.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} The World's Largest Online Frontend Developer Bootcamp|url = https://www.bloc.io/frontend-development-bootcamp|website = Bloc|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> In the Building Real Projects Phase, students will learn frontend frameworks and libraries including jQuery, [[AngularJS]], and JavaScript testing frameworks.
=== User Experience Design === In the Foundation Phase, students will learn the fundamentals of design and the essence of problem solving, while creating brands and websites using [[Adobe Illustrator|Illustrator]], [[Adobe Photoshop|Photoshop]], HTML, CSS and Javascript. Students will have an understanding of responsive design while learning how to launch their finished projects using [[GitHub|Github]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} The World's Largest Online UX Design Bootcamp|url = https://www.bloc.io/ux-design-bootcamp|website = Bloc|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> In the Building Real Projects Phase, students will build projects such as mobile app concepts. Students will learn the principles of user experience and create user flows and wireframes for a web application to understand how these personas can affect the final product. In the last 2 weeks, instead of the usual capstone project, students will build their personal brand and portfolio using the skills acquired from the course.
=== Android Development === In the Foundation Phase, students will set up a developer environment using [[Android Studio]], Github, and their own [[Moto G (2nd generation)|Moto G]] android phone. After gaining an understanding of Java programming concepts, they will also code their first app and deploy to their test phone. In the Building Real Projects Phase, students reinforce their Android developer skills by choosing from a menu of apps to build.
=== iOS Development === In the Foundation Phase, students will set up a developer environment using [[Xcode#6.x series|Xcode6]], [[Git (software)|Git]] and GitHub. Fundamental programming topics such as variables, loops, arrays and objects, are explored using both [[Objective-C]] and [[Swift (programming language)|Swift]]. Students will then learn how to build real apps, [[Test-driven development|test-driven Development]], [[debugging]] and launching their apps.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Learn iOS Programming with a Mentor {{!}} Bloc|url = https://www.bloc.io/ios-bootcamp|website = Bloc|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> In the Build & Ship Phase, students take on open-ended projects with the help of their mentors, learning how to work with [[Application programming interface|APIs]], game dynamics, [[iCloud]] integration and mobile back-ends.
== Scholarships == Bloc offers 2 scholarships, the [[New Relic]] Diversity Scholarship in Software Development and Design and the Veterans Scholarship in Software Development and Design.
=== New Relic Diversity Scholarship in Software Development and Design === In 2013, Bloc and New Relic created this ongoing scholarship to promote diversity in [[software development]] and [[User experience design|UX design]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} Programming Bootcamp Diversity Scholarship|url = http://try.bloc.io/new-relic-bootcamp-diversity-scholarship/|website = try.bloc.io|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref> This scholarship caters to females, veterans of the U.S. military and ethnic minority groups underrepresented in the software engineering field. Recipients of the scholarship will receive $500 partial scholarship toward any Bloc program. Since its inception, it has handed out over 1000 scholarships.
=== Veterans Scholarship in Software Development and Design === Targeted at the U.S. military veterans, this scholarship aims to help by equipping the U.S. veterans with the necessary tools to launch their tech careers. Recipients of the scholarship will receive $500 partial scholarship towards any Bloc program.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bloc {{!}} Online Dev Bootcamp Scholarship for Veterans|url = http://try.bloc.io/dev-bootcamp-for-veterans/|website = try.bloc.io|accessdate = 2015-04-14}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Coursera]] * [[The Data Incubator]] * [[Codecademy]] * [[Khan Academy]] * [[Lynda.com]] * [[App Academy]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=January 2014}} {{primary sources|date=January 2014}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = Boston Bar Association | logo = [[Image:Bbalogo small web.png|200px|Boston Bar Association]] | type = [[Bar Association]] | founded_date = Incorporated 1861 | founder = | location = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = [[Law]] | product = | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.bostonbar.org www.bostonbar.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Boston Bar Association''' ('''BBA''') is a volunteer non-governmental organization in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], United States. With headquarters located at 16 [[Beacon Street]] in the historic [[Chester Harding House]], across from the [[Massachusetts State House]] on [[Beacon Hill, Boston, Massachusetts|Beacon Hill]], the BBA has 11,000<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/about-us</ref> members drawn from private practice, corporations, government agencies, [[legal aid]] organizations, the courts and law schools. It traces its origins to meetings convened by [[John Adams]], the lawyer who provided ''[[pro bono]]'' representation to the British soldiers prosecuted for the [[Boston Massacre]] and went on to become the second president of the United States. [[Image:Boston Bar Association facade.jpg|thumb|The [[Chester Harding House]], a [[National Historic Landmark]] occupied by portrait painter [[Chester Harding (painter)|Chester Harding]] from 1826-1830, now houses the Boston Bar Association.]] [[Image:Boston Bar Association Adams Room.jpg|thumb|John and Abigail Adams Room]]
Governed by a Council of 30 members, the Boston Bar Association has 24 sections and more than 100 committees dedicated to substantive areas of law as well as issues such as access to justice and the administration of justice.
== Public policy == The Association makes its policy positions known ''via'' the filing of [[amicus brief|''amicus'' brief]]s,<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/public-policy public</ref> the drafting of legislation and official comments on proposed government actions. Recent public policy positions taken by the Boston Bar Association include:
'''''March 2012''''': The Boston Bar Association Task Force on the Civil Right to Counsel released "The Importance of Representation in Eviction Cases and Homelessness Prevention <ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/docs/default-document-library/bba-crtc-final-3-1-12.pdf</ref> which recommended pilot projects to learn more about the mechanisms for providing counsel, the effect of creating a right to counsel, the costs involved, and the potential cost savings to the Commonwealth.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/docs/default-document-library/bba-crtc-final-3-1-12.pdf</ref>
'''''October 2011''''': The association released the Report of the Boston Bar Association Task Force on the Future of the Profession<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/docs/default-document-library/future-of-prof-task-force.pdf</ref> in response to the 2008 recession and its effects on the legal market.
'''''May 2011''''': The association released a report, Justice on the Road to Ruin,<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/pub/bw/1011/052311/JusticeontheRoadtoRuinMay2011.pdf</ref> on the Massachusetts State Trial Court’s state budget. The report states that continued inadequate court funding will inflict pain on real people.
'''''March 2010''''': The association's Task Force on the FY 2011 Judiciary Budget released their report.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/prs/nr_0910/Judiciary_Budget_3-8-10.pdf</ref> The Report warns that further cuts to the Judiciary would have severe consequences for the administration of justice in the Commonwealth.<ref>http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/03/bar_association.html</ref>
'''''November 2006''''': The Boston Bar Association, with the [[New York City Bar Association]], the Beverly Hills Bar Association, the [[Los Angeles County Bar Association]] and the [[Bar Association of San Francisco]], filed an ''amicus'' brief in ''[[American Civil Liberties Union]], Et Al. v. [[National Security Agency]], et al.'', a case now pending before the [[U.S. Court of Appeals]] for the Sixth Circuit. The brief urges the Court of Appeals in Cincinnati to affirm a lower court ruling that permanently enjoined the National Security Administration's warrantless surveillance program.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/pp/amicus/aclu_v_nsa.pdf</ref>
'''''September 2005''''': The association was one of a number of organizations which signed on to an ''amicus'' brief in ''United States v. Darryl Green''. In addition, the BBA drafted a petition to the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts urging the Court to revise its jury plan to remedy the under-representation of minorities in the federal jury pool.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/pp/amicus/us_v_green.pdf</ref>
'''''June 2005''''': The association's President-Elect Edward P. Leibensperger testified before the Massachusetts Legislature's Joint Committee on the Judiciary, urging the defeat of all bills related to reinstating [[capital punishment]] in Massachusetts.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/pp/deathpenalty071405.pdf</ref>
'''''September 2002''''': The association filed an ''amicus'' brief in ''[[Goodridge v. Department of Public Health]]'' in support of gay marriage as a [[civil rights]] issue stating that discrimination against gays and lesbians is unacceptable and unconstitutional.<ref>http://www.bostonbar.org/pp/amicus/goodridge_v_dph.pdf</ref>
==Periodicals== Four times a year (winter, spring, summer, fall) the Boston Bar Association publishes a magazine called the ''Boston Bar Journal''.<ref>[http://www.bostonbar.org/about-us/resource-library/boston-bar-journal Boston Bar Journal]</ref> The ''Journal'' is an online publication managed by a volunteer Board of Editors that presents information, analysis, and opinions in articles written by attorneys, judges, and others interested in the development of the law. The ''Journal'' is free to all Association members, and available as well to paid subscribers.
The association also publishes ''BBA Week'', a weekly e-newsletter that provides information on pro bono and public service opportunities, updates from law firms and the state and federal courts, previews of upcoming legal education programs and special events, and photo albums.
In addition, the association's Sections and Committees publish online newsletters.
== Public service == The Boston Bar Association has established public service programs utilizing lawyer volunteers. Among these programs are: * The M. Ellen Carpenter Financial Literacy Program - co-sponsored by the [[U.S. Bankruptcy Court]] for Massachusetts – designed to teach high school students about budgeting, making sound credit choices and avoiding bankruptcy.<ref>''[[The Boston Globe]]'' : [http://www.boston.com/business/personalfinance/articles/2005/05/22/in_1992_young_adults_carried_almost_1500_on_their_credit_cards_by_2001_their_debt_grew_to_nearly_3000/?page=full "In 1992, young adults carried almost $1,500 on their credit cards. By 2001, their debt grew to nearly $3,000"]</ref><ref>''[[The Boston Globe]]'' : [http://www.boston.com/business/personalfinance/articles/2008/05/06/a_crash_course_in_credit/?page=full/ "A crash course in credit"]</ref> * The Boston Bar Association Summer Jobs Program – conducted in partnership with the [[Boston Public Schools]], the [[Boston Youth Fund]], and the Boston Private Industry Council, it places juniors and seniors from Boston's public high schools in paid summer internships at Boston law firms, corporate law departments, and law-related public agencies. * The Lawyer-for-the-Day Project at the Boston Housing Court – provides pro bono lawyers to assist unrepresented tenants and landlords on summary process day.<ref>''[[The Boston Globe]]'': [http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2006/11/29/few_chances_for_lawyers_to_develop_trial_skills/ "Few chances for lawyers to develop trial skills"]</ref> * The Volunteer Lawyers Project of the Boston Bar Association – provides ''pro bono'' civil legal assistance to low-income clients.
==Past presidents== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2014}} Notable past presidents include: * [[John Adams]] (1761-1766) – second President of the United States * [[Ebenezer R. Hoar]] (1879) -- United States Attorney General, 1869-1870 * [[William Gaston]] (1880-1881) - Governor of [[Massachusetts]], 1875-1876 * [[Moorfield Storey]] (1909-1913) – President of the [[American Bar Association]]; first President of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] * Robert W. Meserve (1963-1965) – President of the American Bar Association * John G. Brooks (1972-1974) - President of the [[National Legal Aid & Defender Association]] and a director of the [[Legal Services Corporation]] * John J. Curtin, Jr. (1979-1981) – President of the American Bar Association * Gene D. Dahmen (1987-1988) – first woman to serve as President of the Boston Bar Association * Rudolph F. Pierce (1989-1990) – first African American to serve as President of the Boston Bar Association * Hon. [[Sandra L. Lynch]] (1992-1993) – first woman to serve as chief judge of the [[United States Court of Appeals]] for the [[First Circuit]] * Hon. [[Margaret H. Marshall]] (1991-1992) – first woman [[Chief Justice]] of the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] * Joan A. Lukey (2000-2001) - first woman President of the [[American College of Trial Lawyers]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://bostonbar.org/ Boston Bar Association website] * [http://bostonbar.org/pub/index.htm Boston Bar Association publications] * [http://www.hklaw.com/James-Smeallie/ BBA President James D. Smeallie biography] at [[Holland & Knight]]

SMALLER.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Chris Bishop in 2015 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|4|7|df=y}}<ref name="whoswho">{{Who's Who | surname = BISHOP | othernames = Prof. Christopher Michael| id = U249776 | author=Anon | doi =10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.249776 | year = 2015 | edition = online [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Norwich]]<ref name=whoswho/> | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1959|4|7|df=y}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = [[Cambridge]] | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[Machine learning]]<ref name=googlescholar>{{Google scholar id}}</ref> | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Oxford]] * [[Culham Centre for Fusion Energy]] * [[AEA Technology]] * [[Aston University]] * [[University of Edinburgh]] * [[Microsoft Research]]}} | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Oxford]] (BA) * [[University of Edinburgh]] (PhD)}} | thesis_title = The semi-classical technique in field theory: some applications | thesis_url = http://hdl.handle.net/1842/11984 | thesis_year = 1983 | doctoral_advisor = [[David Wallace (physicist)|David Wallace]]<ref name=phd/> | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRS|FRSE|FREng|size=100%}} | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = |known_for = ''Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning'' (PRML) book | influences = | influenced = | awards ={{Plainlist| * [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]] (2008)<ref name=xmas>[http://www.rigb.org/christmas-lectures/watch/2008/hi-tech-trek 2008 Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]</ref> * [[Turing Lecture]] (2010)}} | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://research.microsoft.com/~cmbishop}} | footnotes = | spouse = }}'''Christopher Michael Bishop''' (born 7 April 1959)<ref name=whoswho/> {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRS|FRSE|FREng}}<ref name=frs>{{cite web|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/christopher-bishop-13381/|title=Christopher Bishop|year=2017 |author=Anon|website=royalsociety.org|publisher=[[Royal Society]]|location=London}}</ref> is the Laboratory Director at [[Microsoft Research|Microsoft Research Cambridge]], [[Professor]] of [[Computer Science]] at the [[University of Edinburgh]] and a [[Fellow]] of [[Darwin College, Cambridge]].<ref name=cmbishop>{{cite web|title=Microsoft Research Cambridge|url=http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/people/cmbishop/index.htm}}</ref>
==Education== Chris obtained a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in Physics from [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]], and a PhD in Theoretical Physics from the [[University of Edinburgh]], with a thesis on quantum field theory supervised by [[David Wallace (physicist)|David Wallace]].<ref name=phd>{{cite thesis|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Edinburgh|title=The semi-classical technique in field theory : some applications|first= Christopher Michael|last=Bishop|date=1983|url=https://www.era.lib.ed.ac.uk/handle/1842/11984|id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.346542}}|website=lib.ed.ac.uk|hdl=1842/11984|oclc=59284998}} {{free access}}</ref><ref name="whoswho"/>
==Research and career== Bishop’s research investigates [[machine learning]]<ref name=frs/> by allowing computers to learn from data and experience.<ref name=cmbishop/><ref name=nn>{{cite book|title=Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|first=Christopher Michael|last=Bishop|year=1995|isbn=9780198538646}}</ref><ref name="TippingBishop1999">{{cite journal|last1=Tipping|first1=Michael E.|last2=Bishop|first2=Christopher M.|title=Probabilistic Principal Component Analysis|journal=Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B|volume=61|issue=3|year=1999|pages=611–622|issn=1369-7412|doi=10.1111/1467-9868.00196}}</ref> His doctoral students include Neil Lawrence.<ref name="lawrencephd">{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=Neil|last=Lawrence |title=Variational inference in probabilistic models |publisher=University of Cambridge |date=2001 |url=http://ulmss-newton.lib.cam.ac.uk/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=22910}}</ref><ref name=mathgene>{{MathGenealogy|83138}}</ref>
===Awards and honours=== [[File:Christoper Bishop Royal Society.jpg|thumb|Chris Bishop at the [[Royal Society]] admissions day in London, July 2017]] Bishop was awarded the [[Tam Dalyell]] prize in 2009<ref>[http://www.ed.ac.uk/news/all-news/bishop-011209 Tam Dalyell Prize]</ref> and the Rooke Medal from the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]] in 2011.<ref>[http://www.raeng.org.uk/news/news-releases/2011/May/world-leading-engineer-set-to-collect-top-prize Royal Academy of Engineering, Rooke Medal]</ref> He gave the [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]] in 2008<ref name=xmas/> and the [[Turing Lecture]] in 2010. Bishop was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering]] (FREng) in 2004<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.raeng.org.uk/news/news-releases/2011/May/world-leading-engineer-set-to-collect-top-prize|title=Royal Academy of Engineering|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 February 2018}}</ref>, a [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] (FRSE) in 2007<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rse.org.uk/fellow/christopher-bishop/|title=Professor Christopher M Bishop FREng FRSE, FRS - The Royal Society of Edinburgh|work=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|access-date=2018-02-01|language=en-GB}}</ref>, and [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] (FRS) in 2017.<ref name=frs/>
==References== {{reflist|35em}} {{FRS 2017}} {{Authority control}}

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Cindy Gallop | image = Cindy gallop speaking cropped.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Lucinda Lee Gallop | birth_date = {{Birth-date and age|1 February 1960}} | birth_place = [[Amersham]], Buckinghamshire, England | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=y|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | known_for = Founder of MakeLoveNotPorn and IfWeRanTheWorld | occupation = CEO and advertising executive }}
'''Lucinda "Cindy" Lee Gallop''' (born 1 February 1960)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dellam.com/english/FI/FITZGERALD%20SHUREY%20TARBUCK%20LLP.html |title=FITZGERALD SHUREY TARBUCK LLP |work=Dellam Corporate Information Ltd. |year=2013 |accessdate=12 June 2013}}</ref> is an English advertising consultant, founder and former chair of the US branch of advertising firm [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty]], and founder of the IfWeRanTheWorld and MakeLoveNotPorn companies.<ref name="forbes">{{cite web|last=Bradshaw|first=Leslie|title=How Cindy Gallop Broke Through the 'Thick Layer of Men' and Became the Counterpoint to Porn|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lesliebradshaw/2011/08/10/how-cindy-gallop-broke-through-the-thick-layer-of-men-and-became-the-counterpoint-to-porn/|work=Forbes|accessdate=25 April 2012|date=8 October 2011}}</ref> According to the TED blog, Gallop's TEDTalk "Make Love Not Porn" was one of the "most talked about presentations" at the 2009 TED conference.<ref name="tedtalks">{{cite web|title=Cindy Gallop: Make Love Not Porn|url=http://blog.ted.com/2009/12/02/cindy_gallop_ma/|publisher=TED|accessdate=26 April 2012|date=2 December 2009}}</ref> She lives in New York City.<ref name="forbes" />
==Early life== Cindy Gallop was born in [[Amersham]], Buckinghamshire, and grew up in [[Brunei]]. She is of half English, half Chinese descent. Gallop's father is English and her mother Malaysian Chinese, from Alor Star in Kedah. Her parents live in Penang, where she returns regularly.
Gallop studied English Literature at [[Somerville College]], [[Oxford University]], receiving an MA in English Language and Literature, followed by an MA from [[Warwick University]] in Theatre of the European Renaissance.<ref name="forbes" />
==Career== Gallop worked as a theatre publicist and marketer in England for several years before switching careers to advertising.<ref name="tedblog">{{cite web |title=Q&A with Cindy Gallop: Tackling porn, feminism and big dreams |url=http://blog.ted.com/2009/12/02/qa_with_cindy_g/ |publisher=TED |date=2 December 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> She joined the London office of British advertising firm [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty]] in 1989 and was responsible for large accounts like [[Coca-Cola]], [[Ray-Ban]], and [[Polaroid Corporation|Polaroid]].<ref name="tedblog" /> In 1996, she helped start the Asia Pacific branch of BBH.<ref name="tedblog" /> She founded the US branch of BBH in 1998 and served as chair of the board. In 2003, Gallop won the Advertising Woman of the Year award from Advertising Women of New York.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web |title=Webdenda |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/19/business/012004webadden.html |work=The New York Times |date=19 January 2004 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> She founded her own brand and business innovation consultancy, Cindy Gallop LLC, in 2006.<ref name="nextwomen">{{cite web |title=Cindy Gallop |url=http://thenextwomen.com/next-women-list/item/cindy-gallop |publisher=The Next Women |year=2012 |accessdate=26 April |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630055233/http://www.thenextwomen.com/next-women-list/item/cindy-gallop |archivedate=30 June 2015 |df= }}</ref> She is known for her tagline: "I like to blow shit up. I am the [[Michael Bay]] of business."<ref name="nytech">{{cite web |url=http://wearenytech.com/19-cindy-gallop-founder-ceo-www-ifwerantheworld-com |title=Cindy Gallop |publisher=We Are NY Tech |date=3 December 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
At the 2009 [[TED (conference)|TED]] conference, Gallop launched the MakeLoveNotPorn web site in a 4-minute TEDTalk that the TED blog described as "one of the event's most talked about."<ref name="tedtalks" /> The goal of MakeLoveNotPorn is to provide a platform for people to post amateur porn videos.<ref name="tedtalks" /> She later published a TED book, ''Make Love Not Porn: Technology's Hardcore Impact on Human Behavior''.<ref name="tedbook">{{cite book |last=Gallop |first=Cindy |title=Make Love Not Porn: Technology's Hardcore Impact on Human Behavior |publisher=TED Books |date=22 February 2011 |asin=B004P1IX9U}}</ref> MakeLoveNotPorn.tv launched in August 2012, a video sharing site designed "to make #realworldsex socially acceptable and socially shareable."<ref name="mlnplaunch">{{cite web |url=http://blog.ted.com/2012/08/14/launched-today-in-beta-makelovenotporn-tv/ |title=Launched today in beta: MakeLoveNotPorn.tv |publisher=TED Blog |accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="Make Love Not Porn Founder Cindy Gallop’s Mission to Disrupt the Porn Industry">{{cite web |url=http://www.glammonitor.com/2015/05/16/make-love-not-porn-founder-cindy-gallops-mission-to-disrupt-the-porn-industry-2/ |title=Make Love Not Porn Founder Cindy Gallop's Mission to Disrupt the Porn Industry |publisher=Glammonitor |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
In January 2010, Gallop launched IfWeRanTheWorld, a web platform designed to turn good intentions into action, by allowing people, brands, and companies to easily perform, trade, and co-ordinate "microactions."<ref name="nextwomen" /> One client of IfWeRanTheWorld is [[Levi's]], who worked with IfWeRanTheWorld to create a campaign to revitalise the manufacturing town of [[Braddock, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="usa">{{cite web |url=http://www.characterblog.com/2010/10/if-levis-ran-the-world-theyd-revitalize-an-all-american-town.php |title=If Levi's ran the world, they'd revitalize an all American Town |last=Chou |first=Jerri |publisher=USA network |date=28 October 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="harvard">{{cite book |title=If We Ran the World |first=Hanna |last=Halaburda |first2=Radka |last2=Dohnalova |first3=Aldo |last3=Sesia |publisher=Harvard Business School |ssrn=2020496 |date=16 March 2011}}</ref> Gallop is a professional public speaker in the areas of advertising, branding, and business strategy and has spoken at TED,<ref name="tedtalks" /> [[South by Southwest|SXSW]],<ref name="sxsw">{{cite web |url=http://austin2011.sched.org/speaker/cindygallop |title=Cindy Gallop: The End of Shame: or, Getting Over Oversharing |publisher=Sched* SXSW 2011 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> the [[Association of National Advertisers]] conference,<ref name="ana">{{cite web |url=http://www.ana.net/miccontent/showvideo/id/anc2010-ifwerantheworld |title=The Future of Advertising: Reinvention for Growth |publisher=Association of National Advertisers |accessdate=27 April 2012 |date=15 October 2010}}</ref> [[Web 2.0 Summit|Web 2.0]],<ref name="web20">{{cite web |url=http://www.web2expo.com/webexny2011/public/schedule/speaker/122836 |title=Speaker: Cindy Gallop |publisher=Web 2.0 Expo New York 2011 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> [[ad:tech]],<ref name="adtech">{{cite web |url=http://www.adotas.com/2005/12/around-the-world-with-bbhs-cindy-gallop-keynote-speaker-adtech-ny-2005/ |title=Around the World with BBH's Cindy Gallop, Keynote Speaker, Ad:Tech NY 2005 |last=Gottlieb |first=Jaime |date=6 December 2005 |publisher=Adotas |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> and other conferences.
==The black apartment==
Gallop's unique black-themed New York apartment was a set for [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]'s music video "[[Nasty Girl (The Notorious B.I.G. song)|Nasty Girl]]."<ref name="apartmenttherapy">{{cite web|url=http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/look-the-black-apartment-64212 |title=Look! Cindy Gallop's Black Apartment |last=Govindan |first=Range |publisher=Apartment Therapy.com |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130117035713/http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/look-the-black-apartment-64212 |archivedate=17 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Her apartment has been profiled by ''[[Dwell (magazine)|Dwell]]'',<ref name="dwell">{{cite web |url=http://www.dwell.com/videos/Bold-Color-Small-Space-The-Black-Apartment.html |title=Bold Color, Small Space: The Black Apartment |last=Nadeau |first=Gary |publisher=Dwell |date=7 August 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413092334/http://www.dwell.com/videos/Bold-Color-Small-Space-The-Black-Apartment.html |archivedate=13 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> Apartment Therapy.com,<ref name="apartmenttherapy" />{{Dead link|date=October 2016}} ''[[The Atlantic]]'',<ref name="atlantic">{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/video/index/250034/ |title=Cindy Gallop's Black Apartment |last=Stone |first=Paul |work=The Atlantic |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209143551/http://www.theatlantic.com/video/index/250034 |archivedate=9 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Selby<ref name="theselby">{{cite web |url=http://www.theselby.com/3_19_10_CindyGallop/index.html |last=Selby |first=Todd |title=Cindy Gallop |publisher=The Selby |date=5 April 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603121456/http://www.theselby.com/3_19_10_CindyGallop/index.html |archivedate=3 June 2012 |df= }}</ref> and ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine,<ref name="newyork">{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/homedesign/fall2006/21947/ |title=Where the Boys Were |last=Schoeneman |first=Deborah |work=New York |date=1 October 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> among many others.
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}}
==External links== * [http://www.cindygallop.com/ Official website] * [http://makelovenotporn.com/ MakeLoveNotPorn website] * {{TED speaker}} ** [http://blog.ted.com/2009/12/02/cindy_gallop_ma/ "Make love, not porn" (TED2009)], also on [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FV8n_E_6Tpc YouTube] * [http://ifwerantheworld.com/ IfWeRanTheWorld website] * [http://vimeo.com/6200961 Video tour of the black apartment for Dwell, by Gary Nadeau] * [https://www.hottopics.ht/stories/consumer/can-make-love-not-porn-make-real-life-sex-shareable/ Can MakeLoveNotPorn take real life sex viral?], ''Hot Topics, 2015'' * [https://www.hottopics.ht/stories/consumer/what-is-sextech-and-why-is-everyone-ignoring-it/ What is sextech and why is everyone ignoring it?], ''Hot Topics, 2015'' * [http://www.thedrum.com/news/2015/10/13/women-want-be-leaders-cindy-gallop-gives-her-view-whether-gender-divide-closing 'Women want to be leaders': Cindy Gallop gives her view on whether the gender divide is closing]'', The Drum, 2015'' * [http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1351884/cindy-gallop-5-ways-change-ratio Cindy Gallop: 5 Ways to change the ratio]'', Marketing Magazine, 2015''
