revision.text:
{{notability|date=May 2015}} {{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} '''Noored Kooli''' ([[Estonian language|Estonian]] for ''Young people to schools'') is a solution to address the critical [[teacher]] shortage in [[Estonia]], drawing inspiration from a similar scheme, [[Teach First]], in the [[United Kingdom]]. Launched on February 6, 2006, Noored Kooli aims to place 10-15 exceptional [[Estonia]]n [[college graduate|graduates]] into the schools that need them the most for a minimum of 2 years.
After this period participants can choose to remain in teaching or move on into other careers where the skills and experience gained from the programme will enable them to become leaders in any field
Noored Kooli participants receive an intensive [[teacher training]] course before entering schools to teach full-time on regular teachers' salaries with an added stipend provided by Noored Kooli.
During their time in schools, participants receive mentoring and support from leaders in education to ensure that they become exceptional and effective teachers.
Beyond the impact in the classroom, Noored Kooli participants take part in training and mentorships from both opinion and business leaders in Estonia.
Noored Kooli enjoys a wide breadth of support from both the public and private sectors.
== See also == * [[Tiigrihüpe]]
==Sources== * {{et icon}} [http://www.nooredkooli.ee/ Noored Kooli official website]
[[Category:Education in Estonia]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Estonia]]
{{Estonia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{about|assistive technology|other uses|Oat (disambiguation)}}
'''OATS''' ("'''Open Source Assistive Technology Software'''") is a [[source code repository]] or "[[Forge (software)|forge]]" for [[assistive technology]] software. It was launched in 2006 <ref>Steve Lee: "[http://eduspaces.net/stevelee/weblog/13994.html OATSoft, a new service and a landmark for Accessibility]", 6 May 2006.</ref> with the goal to provide a one-stop “shop” for end users, clinicians and open-source developers to promote and develop [[open source]] assistive technology software. It also allows users to find other software that is free but not open source,<ref name="projectSummary">OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Info/Project/ProjectSummary/ Project Summary].</ref> and open-source software that is developed elsewhere, for example [[NonVisual Desktop Access|NVDA]],<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/nvda NVDA (Non Visual Desktop Access)].</ref> [[Orca (assistive technology)|Orca]]<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/orca-1 Orca].</ref> and FireVox.<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/fire-vox Fire Vox].</ref>
The OATS website was launched at the end of the OATS project, a one-year pilot project that ended in March 2006, and claimed to be the first open-source repository dedicated to assistive technology.<ref name="projectSummary" /><ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Info/News/pressrelease.2006-05-03.7588301469 OATS Launch Press Release], 3 May 2006.</ref> In April 2006, the [[British Computer Society]] (BCS) announced that it was backing the OATS project;<ref>Justin Richards: "[http://www.computerweekly.com/Articles/2006/04/20/215458/BCS-backs-open-source-project-to-boost-software-for-disabled.htm BCS backs open source project to boost software for disabled users]" ''Computer Weekly'', Thursday 20 April 2006.</ref> in August 2006, the British Computer Society's Open Source Specialist Group organised a meeting about the project.<ref>"[http://ossg.bcs.org/2006/08/11/oats-meeting-aftermath/ OATS Meeting Aftermath]", BCS Open Source Specialist Group Blog, Friday, August 11th 2006.</ref>
The OATS project was made up of five partner organisations co-ordinated by the [[ACE Centre]].<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Info/Project/OatsConsortium/ OATS Consortium].</ref> The OATS repository wants to offer an efficient and intuitive way to access good quality assistive technology.<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Info/Project/ProjectContext Project Context].</ref> The OATS repository offers the following facilities to developers:<ref>OATS: [http://www.oatsoft.org/Forge/Info/hosting-on-oats Hosting on OATS].</ref> * project pages to document and manage a software project, * a code repository ([[Subversion]]), * a project management system ([[Trac]] or Poi).
==See also== * [[AccessApps]] * [[Design for All (in ICT)]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.oatsoft.org/Software OATS Software] - interface to search software * [http://www.oatsoft.org/Forge The OATS Forge] - for developers
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oats}} [[Category:Accessibility]] [[Category:Assistive technology]] [[Category:Free software websites]] [[Category:Free and open-source software organizations]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = OpenEMIS | logo = OpenEMIS Logo.png | logo size = 300px | logo caption = | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | author = [http://www.communitysystemsfoundation.org/ Community Systems Foundation] | developer = [[UNESCO]] | released = | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | programming language = | operating system = Any (web-based application) | platform = [[PHP]] / [[AngularJS]] | size = | language = | genre = [[Education Management Information System]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]], version 3<ref>{{cite web |title=OpenEMIS End User License Agreement |url=https://www.openemis.org/files/resources/OpenEMIS_EULA_en.pdf |accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> | alexa = | website = {{URL|http://www.openemis.org/}} }}
'''OpenEMIS''', or Open [[Education Management Information System]] (EMIS), is an Education Management Information System for the education sector. Its main purpose is to collect, analyze, and report data related to the management of educational activities. Initially conceived by [[UNESCO]], OpenEMIS serves as a response to Member States’ need in the area of tools for educational strategic planning.<ref>Tegegn Nuresu Wako (November 2003). [https://www.openemis.org/files/resources/UNESCO_Educational_Management_Information_Systems_An_Overview_2003_en.pdf "Educational Management Information Systems: An Overview."] NESIS/UNESCO. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> ‘Open’ refers to the software being both [[open-source software|open-source]] under the [[GNU GPL]] and available royalty-free to [[Member states of UNESCO]].<ref name="New Open Source">[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/education/themes/planning-and-managing-education/policy-and-planning/single-view/news/openemis_v2_unesco_launches_a_new_generic_and_open_source_education_management_information_system_emis/ "New, open source database helps track country progress in education".] [[UNESCO]]. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref>
==History== [[File:UNESCO_CSF_logo.jpg|250px|frameless|left|Image on left]] OpenEMIS is an initiative launched by [[UNESCO]]. The initiative is in line with UNESCO's effort to promote EMIS to address the issues of access, equity, quality, and relevance in education and subsequent gaps between Member States in providing an adequate decision support system since early 2000s, in keeping with the [[Education for All]] goals adopted in Dakar in 2000.<ref>UNESCO Almaty Cluster Office and the Ministry of Education of Tajikistan (2002). [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0015/001568/156818eo.pdf "Education Management Information System (EMIS) and the Formulation of Education for All (EFA): Plan of Action, 2002-2015".] Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> OpenEMIS was conceived to be a royalty-free software that can be customized to meet the specific needs of implementing countries, without conditions or restrictions for use,<ref name="New Open Source"/> with the purpose of encouraging country-level capacity development and helping countries upgrade their local skills for managing the tool.<ref name="An Open Source">[http://www.unescobkk.org/education/ict/online-resources/databases/ict-in-education-database/item/article/openemis-an-open-sourced-education-management-information-systems-emis/ "OpenEMIS: An Open-Sourced Education Management Information Systems (EMIS)".] Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> The initiative is coordinated by UNESCO in partnership with a [[nonprofit organization]] (NPO), Community Systems Foundation (CSF) for the implementation and technical support since 2012.
==Architecture== OpenEMIS is a suite of interrelated software solutions that supports data collection (Survey; Classroom; Staffroom), management (Core; School; Integrator), and analysis (Visualizer; Monitoring; Dashboard; Analyzer; DataManager; Profiles).<ref name="An Open Source"/> Each application is designed to provide unique standalone features to support different information management requirements at different levels.<ref>[https://www.openemis.org/products Products.] OpenEMIS. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> These features could be customized and integrated with existing systems. As open-source solutions, OpenEMIS benefits from coding contributions from the larger community. The OpenEMIS Initiative utilizes End-user license agreements and Contributor license agreements to ensure maintenance of standards, quality assurance and that the product remains free from commercialization.<ref>[https://www.openemis.org/resources#w10 Resources >> Agreements.] OpenEMIS. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> [[File:OpenEMIS_Architecture_Diagram_en.png|500px|center|Image on center|OpenEMIS Architecture Diagram]]
==Implementation== OpenEMIS is being implemented in the following countries. In nearly all cases, the Ministry of Education is central to implementation, with support and engagement with a wide range of [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]]:<ref>[https://news.openemis.org/category/project-profiles/ Project Profiles.] OpenEMIS. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref>
* Malaysia ([[UNHCR]] [[Malaysia]], 2012–present) * Grenada ([[OECS]], 2013–present) * St. Vincent and the Grenadines ([[OECS]], 2013–present) * Belize (Ministry of Education, Youth, Sports & Culture of [[Belize]], 2014–present) * Jordan ([[UNESCO]] [[Jordan]], 2014–present) * Maldives (Ministry of Education of [[Maldives]], 2015–present) * Turks and Caicos Islands (Ministry of Education of [[Jordan]], 2016–present)
==Support== Support is available to implementing countries with all aspects of country implementation from the technical support team. Support activities include services for: Policy and Planning; Analysis; Implementation; Custom Software Development; Training; and others as needed.<ref>[https://www.openemis.org/services#w4 Services.] OpenEMIS. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref> System set up may involve cost for additional technical support for setup, configuration, migration, and capacity building.<ref>[https://www.openemis.org/about#w1 "What is the cost of OpenEMIS?"] OpenEMIS. Retrieved 11 July 2016.</ref>
==See also== * [[Datamining]] * [[PHP]] * [[Web 2.0]] * [[Sustainable Development Goals]] (SDG) Goal: Quality Education (SDG4) Targets
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.openemis.org OpenEMIS]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Pervin Shroff |birth_place = [[India]] |nationality = [[India]] |fields = [[Financial Accounting]] |alma_mater = [[Columbia University]]
[[University of Mumbai]] }} '''Pervin Keki Shroff''' (born c. 1955) is an Indian accounting academic and Carl L. Nelson Professor of Accounting at the [[Carlson School of Management]], [[University of Minnesota]], known for her work in the field of [[information content]] and accountancy.Hail, Luzi, and Christian Leuz. "International differences in the cost of equity capital: Do legal institutions and securities regulation matter?." Journal of accounting research 44.3 (2006): 485-531.Hribar, Paul, and Nicole Thorne Jenkins. "The effect of accounting restatements on earnings revisions and the estimated cost of capital." Review of accounting studies 9.2-3 (2004): 337-356. == Biography == Shroff obtained her Bachelor of Commerce in 1976 at the [[Bombay University]] (now the [[University of Mumbai]]), and her Bachelor of Laws in 1979. She also obtained her licence as [[Institute of Chartered Accountants of India|Chartered Accountant in India]], and obtained her PhD in accounting at [[Columbia University]] in 1992. She is an Accredited Management Accountant, through the Institute of Cost and Management Accountants, London (now known as the [[Chartered Institute of Management Accountants]]) and is also an Accredited Corporate Secretary, through the [[Institute of Company Secretaries of India]].[http://carlsonschool.umn.edu/faculty/pervin-shroff Profile of Pervin Shroff]; www.carlsonschool.umn.edu. Accessed 11-03-2015. ==Selected publications== * Pervin Keki Shroff. ''Essays on the Association of Accounting Earnings with Security Returns,'' Columbia University, 1992. * Pervin Keki Shroff, ''Determinants of the Returns-earnings Correlation,'' 1993. ;Articles, a selection: * Ohlson, James A., and Pervin K. Shroff. "Changes versus levels in earnings as explanatory variables for returns: Some theoretical considerations." ''Journal of Accounting Research'' (1992): 210-226. * D'mello, Ranjan, and Pervin K. Shroff. "[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.39.1153&rep=rep1&type=pdf Equity undervaluation and decisions related to repurchase tender offers: An empirical investigation]." ''The Journal of Finance'' 55.5 (2000): 2399-2424. * Easton, P., Taylor, G., Shroff, P., & Sougiannis, T. (2002). "[http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/kli/papers/Easton_et_al-2002JF.pdf Using forecasts of earnings to simultaneously estimate growth and the rate of return on equity investment]." ''Journal of Accounting Research,'' 40(3), 657-676. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://carlsonschool.umn.edu/faculty/pervin-shroff Pervin Shroff, Carl L. Nelson Professorship in Accounting] {{DEFAULTSORT:Shroff, Pervin}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian accountants]] [[Category:Accounting academics]] [[Category:Columbia Business School alumni]] [[Category:University of Mumbai alumni]] [[Category:University of Minnesota faculty]] [[Category:Indian business writers]] [[Category:Parsi people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website |name = |logo = Publons logo.png |logo_size = 300px |screenshot = |caption = |collapsible = |collapsetext = |url = {{URL|https://publons.com/}} |slogan = |commercial = |type = |registration = |language = English |num_users = 200,000 |owner = [[Clarivate Analytics]] |author = |revenue = |footnotes = |logocaption = |content license = |launch date = 2012 |current status = Online }} '''Publons''' is a website and free service for academics to track, verify and showcase their [[post-publication peer review|peer review]] and editorial contributions for academic journals. It was launched in 2012 and by 2017 more than 200,000 researchers have joined the site, adding more than one million reviews across 25,000 journals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/careers/2016/02/getting-credit-peer-review|title=Getting credit for peer review|last=Ravindran|first=Sandeep|date=2016-02-08|website=Science|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref><ref>Spence, Paul: [http://idealog.co.nz/venture/2016/09/wellington-startups-stayed "Wellington startups that stayed up"], in ''Idealog'', 15 September 2016</ref><ref>https://publons.com/blog/spread-of-peer-review-workload/</ref> Publons' mission is to "speed up science by harnessing the power of peer review".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Publons|url = https://publons.com/about/|website = publons.com|accessdate = 2016-06-16}}</ref> Publons claims that by turning peer review into a measurable research output, academics can use their review and editorial record as evidence of their standing and influence in their field. Publons says its business model is based on partnering with publishers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://publons.freshdesk.com/support/solutions/articles/5000543451-what-is-publons-business-model-|title=What is Publons' business model? : Publons|website=publons.freshdesk.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-15}}</ref>
Publons produces a verified record of a person's review and editorial activity for journals. This evidence is showcased on reviewers' online profiles and can be downloaded to include in CVs, funding and job applications, and promotion and performance evaluations.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Peer review is essential to good science – it's time to credit expert reviewers |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/jun/01/peer-review-is-essential-to-good-science-its-time-to-credit-expert-reviewers|last=Curry|first=Stephen|date=2017-06-01|website=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-01}}</ref>
Publons also provides: * tools for publishers to find, screen, contact, and motivate peer reviewers; * data and publications about global peer review behaviour; * peer review training for early-career researchers; and * features for academics to discuss and evaluate published research. Reviewers can choose whether or not to make the content of their review [[open access]] following publication of the reviewed publication, though journals can choose to override this. Review content is shared using a [[Creative Commons]] CC BY 4.0 [[Creative Commons license|license]]. It has partnerships with major publishers, including [[Springer Nature]], [[Taylor and Francis]], [[Oxford University Press]], [[BMJ (company)|BMJ]], [[SAGE Publications|SAGE]], [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] and [https://publons.com/community/our-partners/ more], and with related services such as [[Altmetric]] and [[ORCID]].
== Background == Publons was founded by Andrew Preston and Daniel Johnston to address the static state of peer-reviewing practices in academic research publishing, in view of encouraging collaboration and speeding scientific development.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Future of Academic Research|url = http://figshare.com/articles/The_Future_of_Academic_Research/871466|doi = 10.6084/m9.figshare.871466|last = Preston|first = Andrew|first2 = Daniel|last2 = Johnston}} {{open access}}</ref> The Publons name is an homage to the "publon", the "[[Least publishable unit|minimum unit of publishable material]]". The company is registered in New Zealand and has an office in London, UK.
Publons was acquired by [[Clarivate Analytics]] in 2017. Clarivate's citation network and researcher tools, including products like [[Web of Science]], [[EndNote]], and [[ScholarOne]], has generated customers in more than 100 countries and 7,000 institutions.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Page|first1=Benedicte|title=Clarivate Analytics buys Publons|url=https://www.thebookseller.com/news/clarivate-analytics-buys-publons-562691|access-date=2017-11-01|work=The Bookseller}}</ref> Publons — which continues to run as a stand-alone business - say the partnership will bring more transparency, recognition, and training to peer review, helping to solve some of the critical problems facing research today.<ref>https://publons.com/blog/publons-joins-clarivate-analytics/</ref> This includes speeding up research by helping editors find skilled and motivated peer reviewers, and tackling issues such as peer review fraud.<ref>{{cite news|title=Web of Science owner buys up booming peer-review platform|url=https://www.nature.com/news/web-of-science-owner-buys-up-booming-peer-review-platform-1.22094|access-date=2017-11-01|work=Nature}}</ref>
== Publons Academy == The Publons Academy is Publons' peer review training course for early-career researchers.<ref>https://publons.com/community/academy/</ref> The free, online course requires students to practice writing real reviews that are assessed by a supervisor. Upon completion of the course, graduate reviewers are made discoverable to Publons partner journals on the site who can invite these reviewers to perform real pre-publication peer reviews.
== Publons Peer Review Awards == Publons Peer Review Awards<ref>https://publons.com/awards/</ref> are recognitions for top peer reviewers and editors. Publons' Awards started in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the world's top peer reviewer|url=https://www.statnews.com/2016/09/23/meet-the-worlds-top-peer-reviewer/|access-date=2017-11-01|work=Stat News}}</ref> In 2017 an award program called the Sentinel Award was added, for outstanding advocacy, innovation or contribution to scholarly peer review.<ref>{{cite news|title=Time to open the curtains on peer review|url=https://www.natureindex.com/news-blog/time-to-open-the-curtains-on-peer-review|access-date=2017-11-01|work=Nature Index}}</ref>
== Reception == [[TechCrunch]] remarked that lack of transparency leads to many problems in the publication process, and Publons purports to help with that.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shu|first1=Catherine|title=Academic Startup Publons Gives Peer Reviewers Credit For Their Work|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/10/08/academic-startup-publons-gives-peer-reviewers-credit-for-their-work/|accessdate=5 September 2014|work=Techcrunch}}</ref> ''Research Information'' noted that while the site supports both pre- and post-publication review, not all reviews are published, in deference to existing publication norms.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Sian|title=Tracking and Validating Reviews|url=http://www.researchinformation.info/features/feature.php?feature_id=448|website=Research Information|publisher=Europa Science Limited|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref> ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' noted that peer review is an important job, and reported on the reactions of two of Publons's most prolific reviewers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=van Noorden|first1=Richard|title=The scientists who get credit for peer review|url=http://www.nature.com/news/the-scientists-who-get-credit-for-peer-review-1.16102|website=Nature|publisher=Nature Publishing Group|accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref>
Publons sends [[unsolicited bulk email]] to academics to advertise its service. This was cited by [[Mailbox provider|email service providers]] for being violation of acceptable use policies.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ScientificSpam DNSBL on Twitter|url = https://twitter.com/scientificspam/status/621620534426628096|website = Twitter|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Journal club]] * [[JournalReview.org]] * [[PubPeer]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://publons.com/ Publons home page]
{{Academic publishing}}

revision.text:
Professor '''Reuben James Olembo''' (1937 - 2005) was a prominent Kenyan academic, scientist and environmentalist. He was a Deputy Executive Director of the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP), which he played a pivotal role in helping found, and United Nations Assistant Secretary General from 1994-1998.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.unep.org/Documents.Multilingual/Default.asp?DocumentID=429&ArticleID=4753&l=en |title=Speeches - March 2005 - The Passing Away of An Environmental Icon: Prof. Reuben Olembo - United Nations Environment Programme |publisher=UNEP |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> He became the Acting Secretary General of the [[CITES|Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora]] (CITES),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cites.org/eng/disc/what.php |title=What is |publisher=CITES |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> after his retirement from UNEP.
==Early life== Reuben Olembo was born on November 28, 1937 in [[Bunyore]] in the then Vihiga District of Kakamega in [[Western Province (Kenya)|Western Province]], Kenya. He excelled in his studies at Wanakhale Primary School, and then Maseno School, both of which were [[mission school]]s. Faith played a key role in his early family life and education. His parents were both ministers in the [[Church of God (Cleveland, Tennessee)|Church of God]], established in his village by American missionaries.{{cn|date=October 2016}}
Olembo was among the students airlifted to the US in 1959 as part of the [[The Kennedy Airlift|Mboya airlifts]].<ref name=DailyNation1>{{cite web|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/lifestyle/Top-Kenyan-students-flying-high-in-America/-/1214/2842452/-/rmxjk2z/-/index.html|title=They were given wings and are now flying high in top American multinationals|work=[[Daily Nation]]|date=22 August 2015|author=Vincent Achuka}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-33629577|title=The airlift education scholarship that changed the world|publisher=BBC|date=23 July 2015|author=Milton Nkosi}}</ref> He attended [[Purdue University]] in [[Indiana]]{{cn|date=October 2016}} and between 1961 and 1965 he was awarded his bachelor's (Biology and Chemistry), master's and doctoral degrees (genetics, with minors in biochemistry and statistics).<ref name="google1">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7PPAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA57 |title=Kenyan Student Airlifts to America 1959-1961: An Educational Odyssey |last=Stephens |first=Robert F. |publisher=Kenway Publications |year=2014}}</ref> His academic accomplishments were notable because "he did not come from a scientific background and had no laboratory experience."<ref name="google1"/>
Olembo taught at [[Makerere University]] in Uganda between 1965 and 1969, where he earned the nickname "Prof." He is said to have helped many Ugandans enter the UN system through scholarships and was instrumental in the establishment of Makerere University's National Institute for Environment.
Olembo moved back to Kenya to join the Department of Botany at the [[University of Nairobi]]. He was appointed chairman of the department in 1970, aged 33. He remained in that position till 1975. He was the first Kenyan to be a professor in the department and to head it.<ref>{{cite web|author=School of Biological Sciences |url=http://sbs.uonbi.ac.ke/node/2286 |title=Prof., REUBEN J. OLEMBO CHAIRMAN FORMER BOTANY DEPARTMENT, 1970 - 1975 | School of Biological Sciences |publisher=Sbs.uonbi.ac.ke |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> He introduced new, rigorous courses in genetics at both the undergraduate and post-graduate levels.
Olembo was a strong advocate for education in Kenya and neighboring countries. He served as an examiner for the Cambridge University School Certificate, a chief examiner for the East African Examinations Council, and an external assessor for university degrees in Nigeria, Ghana, and Tanzania.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ag.purdue.edu/agalumni/Lists/DAA/DispForm.aspx?ID=149 |title=DAA - Reuben J. Olembo |publisher=Ag.purdue.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref>
He wrote and was widely published on genetics, ecology and environmental policy.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qThSUMiDXr8C&pg=PA209 |title=Partnerships for Global Ecosystem Management: Science, Economics, and Law ... |publisher= |year=}}</ref>
==International career==
Olembo was a member of the African delegation to the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment|1972 Stockholm Conference]] that led to the creation of UNEP. He joined the organisation in 1974 as a Senior Programme Officer. He played key roles in strengthening a number of Multilateral Environmental Agreements (MEAS), such as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna (CITES), the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the UN Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD), and the FAO International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
He chaired and spoke at numerous international conferences on environmental matters.
==National career==
Olembo was the longest serving member of the Board of Trustees of the [[Kenya National Parks]], to which he was appointed in 1967.
While at the University of Nairobi, Olembo helped members of parliament from Western Kenya build the Harambee Institute of Technology for Western Province, which became the Western College of Arts and Applied Sciences (WECO) and which, in 2007 became the [[Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmust.ac.ke/index.php/historical-background.html |title=Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology |publisher=Mmust.ac.ke |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref>
Olembo served as a national government advisor on environmental affairs to the Minister of Environment and Natural Resources. He developed the blueprint for what became the National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA).<ref>{{cite web|author=PrevNext |url=http://www.nema.go.ke/index.php?option=com_content&view=featured&Itemid=101 |title=Welcome to the National Environment Management Authority |publisher=Nema |date= |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> He was then appointed a managing trustee of the Kenya National Environment Trust Fund. He joined the Board of Directors of the Kenya Seed Company<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kenyaseed.com |title=Welcome to Kenya Seed Co.Ltd |publisher=Kenyaseed.com |date=2012-10-13 |accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> in 2003, where he served until his death in March 2005 after participating in a company strategic planning retreat.<ref>http://allafrica.com/stories/200503230946.html</ref>
==Recognition== Purdue University honored Olembo in 1994 with a Distinguished Alumni Award for Agriculture.<ref>http://purduealumni.org/pbao/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Insights_Spring07.pdf</ref> He was also a Rockefeller Foundation Fellow, a Fellow of the Kenya Academy of Sciences (secretary) and a member of the International Genetics Federation (executive committee).{{cn|date=October 2016}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Olembo, Reuben}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Kenyan environmentalists]] [[Category:Kenyan officials of the United Nations]] [[Category:University of Nairobi academics]] [[Category:Purdue University alumni]] [[Category:Scholarships in the United States]]

{{Infobox person | name = Reuven Adiv | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Reuven Adiv | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1930|06|05}} | birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2004|12|23|1930|06|05}} | death_place = [[London]], England | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Drama teacher, director, actor | known_for = Head of acting at the [[Drama Centre London|Drama Centre]] in London (1984–2004) }} '''Reuven Adiv''' ({{lang-he|ראובן אדיב}}; 5 June 1930–23 December 2004) was a Jerusalem-born actor, director and drama teacher, most notable as the head of acting at the [[Drama Centre London|Drama Centre]] in London from 1984 to 2004.{{cite web |last=Newley|first=Patrick|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/2005/08/final-farewell/|title=Final farewell|publisher=www.thestage.co.uk|year=2004|accessdate=5 May 2013}} ==Early life== Reuven Adiv was born in Jerusalem on 5 June 1930. He fought on the Jerusalem front against the British administration. His father was born in part of modern-day Belarus, and died in a [[Nazi concentration camps|Nazi concentration camp]]. ==Career== His early acting experience came at the [[Culture of Israel#Theater|Ohel Theatre]] and the Kameri Theatre in [[Tel Aviv]]. He studied under [[Lee Strasberg]] at the [[Actors Studio]] in New York, where he also took the director's course. He also studied at the film school of [[New York University]] before returning to teach at the Lee Strasberg institute. He returned to Tel Aviv in 1971 and alongside stage and screen acting he was invited to teach at the [[Beit Zvi]] school of performing arts. In 1979 he was appointed principal of the theatre department of Seminar HaKibbutzim college. In 1984, he was invited to become head of the acting department at the Drama Centre, London as a successor to [[Doreen Cannon]], who had become head of acting at the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] (RADA).
"...the results emanate from within, owing nothing to make-up or setting..." - Reuven Adiv{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10150174540024685&id=168465699684|title=PeachCraft Studios of Drama, Voice & Filmmaking |publisher=PDVF |date=|accessdate=7 May 2013}}
From 1986 to 1996, he was a guest teacher at the Swedish State Theatre School, Gothenburg and from 2003 he taught at the Forum für Filmschauspiel in Berlin. ===Notable students=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Morven Christie]]{{cite web |url=http://blueteam.clickgarden.net/isa.html|title=Cast List, Morven Christie - Isa Morrison|publisher=blueteam.clickgarden.net|date=|accessdate=7 May 2013}} * [[Benjamin Davies (actor)|Benjamin Davies]]{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} * [[Colin Firth]] {{col-break}} * [[Tara Fitzgerald]] * [[Ruta Gedmintas]]{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/ruta-gedmintas/bio/330969|title=Ruta Gedmintas: Biography|publisher=www.tvguide.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * [[Martin Goeres]] {{col-break}} * [[Helen McCrory]] * [[John Simm]] {{col-end}} ===Selected stage productions as director=== * ''[[The Crucible]]'', [[Drama Centre London]] (2003){{cite web |url=http://www.alphaactors.com/actors/male/les-kenny-green/|title=Les Kenny-Green |publisher=www.alphaactors.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Maria (play)|Marya]]'', Drama Centre London (2003){{cite web |url=http://www.leadingroleagency.co.uk/male_actors/shane-chester/|title=Shane Chester - Stage|publisher=www.leadingroleagency.co.uk|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Paradise Lost (play)|Paradise Lost]]'', Drama Centre London (2002) * ''[[This Happy Breed]]'' by [[Noël Coward]], Drama Centre London (2002) * ''[[:it:Napoli milionaria!|Napoli Millionaria]]'' by [[Eduardo De Filippo]], Drama Centre London (2001) * ''[[Tartuffe]]'', Drama Centre London (2000){{cite web |url=https://actors.mandy.com/uk/castactorcv.asp?actorid=79618104&cdid=0|title=Sean Knopp - Stage|publisher=www.mandy.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[The Seagull]]'', Drama Centre London (1999){{cite web |url=http://actors.mandy.com/uk/view.php?uid=258721|title=Anita Koh|publisher=www.mandy.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Six Characters in Search of an Author]]'' by [[Luigi Pirandello]], Drama Centre London (n.d.){{cite web |url=http://www.mariodemetriou.com/cv.html|title=Mario Demetriou - CV|publisher=www.mariodemetriou.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * [[Henrik Ibsen|Ibsen's]] ''[[A Doll's House]]'', Drama Centre London (n.d.){{cite web |url=http://daamanagement.co.uk/clients_detail.asp?id=272|title=Helen Millar - Theatre|publisher=daamanagement.co.uk|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Spring Awakening (play)|Spring Awakening]]'', Drama Centre London (n.d.){{cite web |url=http://unitedagents.co.uk/ruta-gedmintas|title=Ruta Gedmintas - Stage|publisher=unitedagents.co.uk|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Enemies, a Love Story (play)|Enemies]]'', Drama Centre London (n.d.){{cite web |url=http://unitedagents.co.uk/poppy-elliott|title=Poppy Elliott - Stage|publisher=unitedagents.co.uk|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} * ''[[Right You Are (If You Think You Are)]]'', Drama Centre London (n.d.){{cite web |url=http://roykhalil.moonfruit.com/#/resume/4514404470|title=Roy Khalil - Stage|publisher=roykhalil.moonfruit.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} ==Personal life== He married the Israeli actress and broadcaster [[Galia Nativ]] in 1980. They had two children, a daughter and a son,{{cite web |last=Fettes|first=Christopher|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/jan/31/guardianobituaries|title=Obituary, Reuven Adiv, Inspirational drama teacher |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk|date=31 January 2005|accessdate=5 May 2013}} and lived in North London.{{cite web |url=http://www.192.com/atoz/people/nativ-adiv/galia/|title=Galia Nativ-adiv|publisher=www.192.com|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} He died of a heart attack in 2004, aged 74. ==Filmography== * 1976 ''[[Giv'at Halfon Eina Ona]]'' (English: ''[[Giv'at Halfon Eina Ona|Halfon Hill Doesn't Answer]]''), directed by [[Assi Dayan]], Israel - Cast member{{cite web |url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b8123e797|title=Giv'at Halfon Eina Ona|publisher=British Film Institute|date=|accessdate=5 May 2013}} ==See also== *[[Method acting]] *[[Drama Centre London]] *[[Actors Studio]] *[[Beit Zvi]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/2005/08/final-farewell/ Obituary at The Stage] *[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/jan/31/guardianobituaries Obituary at The Guardian] *[http://www.photographersdirect.com/buyers/stockphoto.asp?imageid=657856 Portrait (B&W): Reuven Adiv] {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adiv, Reuven}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:People from Jerusalem]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Israeli people of Belarusian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Actors Studio alumni]] [[Category:Israeli male stage actors]] [[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:Drama Centre London]] [[Category:Israeli male film actors]]

{{redirect|RUSI||Rusi (disambiguation)}} {{COI|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox organization |name = Royal United Services Institute |image = Rusilogo.png |image_size = 250px |abbreviation = RUSI |motto = |founder = {{longitem|[[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]]}} |formation = {{start date and age|1831}} |type = {{longitem|[[International security]] and [[Military|defence]] [[think tank]]}} |headquarters = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Royal Highness|HRH]] the [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent|Duke of Kent]] |leader_title2 = {{nowrap|Director-General}} |leader_name2 = Karin von Hippel | status = [[nonprofit organization]]<ref>[http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=210639&subid=0 Charity Commission]</ref> |website = [http://www.rusi.org www.rusi.org] }}
The '''Royal United Services Institute for Defence and Security Studies''' ('''RUSI'''), sometimes still referred to by its pre-2004 name, the '''Royal United Services Institution''', is a [[United Kingdom|British]] defence and security [[think tank]]. It was founded in 1831 by the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington, Sir Arthur Wellesley]].<ref name = "Royal United Services Institute (Biographical details)_2018">{{ cite web | title = Royal United Services Institute (Biographical details) | url = http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=174682 | publisher = The British Museum, UK | language = en | accessdate = 2018-07-23 }}</ref>. RUSI is an independent, non-government and non-partisan organisation registered <ref>[http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=210639&subid=0 registered]</ref> with the UK's Charity Commission.
RUSI's President is [[Royal Highness|HRH]] the [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent|Duke of Kent]] and its Director is Karin von Hippel.
== History == RUSI was founded in 1831 – making it the oldest defence and security think tank in the world – at the initiative of the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]]. Its original mission was to study naval and military science.
The Duke of Wellington spearheaded the establishment of RUSI in a letter to ''Colbourn's United Service Journal'' arguing that "a United Service Museum" should be formed, managed entirely by naval and military officers, and under patronage of the monarch, then [[King George IV]], and the commanders-in-chief of the armed forces. Such an institution would prove that the two professions have entered the lists of science, and are ready to contend for honours ''tam Artibus quam Armis'' – 'as much through the arts as through weapons'.<ref name = "Royal United Services Institute (Biographical details)_2018" />
Subsequently, Commander Henry Downes, Royal Navy, assembled a group with a view to forming a committee for action, to which King George's First ADC was commanded to convey "His Majesty's gracious and high approbation of the undertaking and of the principles on which it is proposed to conduct it", which were stated to be suitable for "a strictly scientific and professional society, and not a club". The death of the King delayed matters, but the [[William IV of the United Kingdom|Duke of Clarence]] expressed his readiness to become a patron so, encouraged by the powerful support of the Duke of Wellington, the First [[Aide-de-camp]], [[Herbert Taylor (Major General)|Sir Herbert Taylor]], re-submitted the project to [[William IV of the United Kingdom|William IV]] (the former Duke of Clarence), and was able to assure the committee that "it could proceed under his Majesty's gracious auspices".
On 25 June 1831 the committee met. The chair was taken by [[Howard Douglas|Major General Sir Howard Douglas]], in his person a symbol of the "United Service": a soldier who was the leading expert on naval gunnery. The resolution that the institution be established was put by the future Field Marshal [[Henry Hardinge, 1st Viscount Hardinge|Viscount Hardinge]] and seconded by the future [[Francis Beaufort|Rear-Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort]], the famous hydrographer. The first name adopted was the '''Naval and Military Museum''': this was altered in 1839 to the '''United Service Institution''', and in 1860 to the '''Royal United Service Institution''' by a [[royal charter|royal charter of incorporation]]. In 2004 the name was changed to the '''Royal United Services Institute for Defence and Security Studies'''. Fellows of RUSI may use the five-letter post-nominal abbreviation, '''FRUSI'''.
===Premises=== Prior to moving into its current purpose-built headquarters in 1895, RUSI began its existence in Whitehall Court, then moved to a house in what was then known as Middle [[Great Scotland Yard (street)|Scotland Yard]] in 1832. Queen Victoria granted RUSI the use of the [[Banqueting House]]. It finally moved to its current location next door to the Banqueting House in 1895.<ref name = "Royal United Services Institute (Biographical details)_2018" />
== Activities == RUSI is a British institution, but operates with an international perspective. It promotes the study and discussion of developments in military doctrine, defence management and defence procurement. In recent years RUSI has broadened its remit to include all issues of defence and security, including financial and organised crime, terrorism and the ideologies which foster it and the challenges which we face from other man-made or man-assisted threats and from natural disasters. The 2016-2017 Review and Annual Report are available <ref name="rusi.org">https://rusi.org/rusi-reports/annual-report-2016-17</ref> It won ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine's Think Tank of the Year Award in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/2008/10/and-the-prospect-2008-think-tank-of-the-year-is/ |title=Prospect Magazine's Think Tank of 2008 |publisher=Prospectmagazine.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref> In 2009, the same magazine named RUSI "Foreign Policy Think Tank of the Year".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/2009/10/prospect-think-tank-of-the-year-the-winners/ |title=Prospect Think Tank of the Year: The Winners |publisher=Prospect Magazine |date= |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref>. In 2018, the awards shortlisted <ref>[https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/sponsored/think-tank-awards-2018-the-full-shortlist shortlisted]</ref> RUSI in the Economic and Financial as well as the International Affairs categories.
RUSI has a membership consisting of military officers, diplomats and the wider policy community, numbering 1,668 individuals and 129 corporate members (see last page of the latest Review) <ref name="https://rusi.org/rusi-reports/annual-report-2016-17"/>
RUSI currently also has fifty Associate Fellows and twelve Fellows FRUSI.
RUSI members and the wider defence and security community have access to the following activities:
=== Research === According to its website <ref>[https://rusi.org/expertise website]</ref>, RUSI 'maintains a wide range of multidisciplinary research specialisms. It focuses on the areas of Military Sciences, International Security Studies, National Security and Resilience Studies, Nuclear Proliferation, Financial Crime and Defence, Industries and Society.'
=== Analysis === RUSI experts are often called upon to provide analysis and commentary on the leading defence and security issues of the day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/news?q=Royal%20United%20Services%20Institute&hl=en&lr=&sa=N&tab=wn |title=Royal United Services Institute |publisher=News.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref> In addition, RUSI.org hosts timely analysis<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rusi.org/commentary |title=Timely analysis |publisher=Rusi.org |date= |accessdate=2018-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207033424/http://www.rusi.org/analysis/ |archivedate=2013-12-07 |df= }}</ref> on the defence and security issues of the day. Content is drawn from its publications and briefings from its researchers.
=== Events === RUSI organises a number of lectures, seminars and conferences for its membership and the wider defence and international security community. Its location in Whitehall means that is able to attract leading statesmen and policymakers.
=== Publications === RUSI publishes a number of periodicals and books. Its flagship publication is the ''[[RUSI Journal]]''. It also publishes the ''RUSI Newsbrief'' and ''RUSI Defence Systems''.
==Governance==
===Funding=== RUSI is a registered charity (No. 210639). It relies on membership subscriptions; income from conferences including sponsorship; research contracts; room hire; and donations from foundations and individuals for its income. RUSI receives no core funding from government.<ref>http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=210639&SubsidiaryNumber=0</ref>. [[Transparify]] gave RUSI a <ref>[https://static1.squarespace.com/static/52e1f399e4b06a94c0cdaa41/t/5b4cfa3d758d463a3bfb54ac/1531771467608/Transparify+2018+Think+Tanks+Report.pdf 4-star]</ref> transparency rating in 2018.
=== Patron === * Her Majesty [[Elizabeth II]]
=== President === * [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] HRH the [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent|Duke of Kent]]
=== Chairman === * The Rt Hon the [[William Hague|Lord Hague of Richmond]]
=== Senior Vice President === * General [[David Petraeus]], [[US Army]]. Rtd.
=== Vice Chairman === * [[John Scarlett|Sir John Scarlett]]
=== Council === RUSI is governed by a Council comprising Vice-Presidents, Trustees and an Advisory Council. Members serve for a three-year term. An up-to-date list can be found on RUSI's website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rusi.org/about/council/ |title=List of members of RUSI Council |publisher=Rusi.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806064410/http://www.rusi.org/about/council/ |archivedate=2013-08-06 |df= }}</ref>
* Vice-Presidents ** Dr James Hay ** The Rt Hon the [[John Hutton, Baron Hutton of Furness|Lord Hutton]] ** Vice-Admiral Rory McLean, RN. Rtd.
=== Director-General === * Karin von Hippel
=== Deputy Director-General === * Professor Malcolm Chalmers
==See also== *[[List of UK think tanks]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rusi.org/ Royal United Services Institute for Defence and Security Studies]

{{BLP primary sources|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ruthe Farmer | image = File:Ruthe Farmer.png | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = from Flickr | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (DEATH date then BIRTH date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Policymaker, activist | years_active = 2001– | known_for = [[Computer science education]] | notable_works = }} '''Ruthe Farmer''' is an American policymaker and activist focused on increasing girls' participation in technology and engineering. Farmer is currently the [[Chief Evangelist]] for the [[CSforAll Consortium]] and she was a senior policy advisor for tech inclusion at the [[White House Office of Science and Technology Policy]] in the [[Obama administration]]<ref name="White House">{{cite web|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/author/ruthe-farmer |title=Ruthe Farmer: Senior Policy Advisor for Tech Inclusion |publisher=Obama White House Archives}}</ref> and Chief Strategy and Growth Officer at the [[National Center for Women & Information Technology]].<ref name="NCWIT">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncwit.org/profile/ruthe-farmer |title=Ruthe Farmer |publisher=National Center for Women & Information Technology}}</ref>
==Background== Farmer attended [[Lewis & Clark College]] between 1988 and 1992, where she received a [[B.A.]] in Communications and German. She attended the [[Saïd Business School]] at [[Oxford University]] between 2007 and 2008, where she received a [[M.B.A.]] in Social Entrepreneurship.<ref name="Abie"/><ref name = "LinkedIn">{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/ruthefarmer/ |title=Ruthe Farmer |publisher=LinkedIn}}</ref>
==Career== Farmer worked for the [[Girl Scouts of the USA|Girl Scouts]] between 2001 and 2007 as a program manager for [[STEM education]] and was a founding committee member of the Oregon Robotics and Tournament Outreach Program, a successful [[FIRST Lego League]] program.<ref name="Abie"/><ref name="LinkedIn"/> She was chair of the 2012 [[Computer Science Education Week]] and subsequently became the Director of Strategic Initiatives for the [[National Center for Women & Information Technology|NCWIT]] between 2008 and 2016. Farmer was named a "Champion of Change for Technology Inclusion" by the White House in 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RXZbWwHWF5U |title=Champions of Change: Tech Inclusion |publisher=The Obama White House}}</ref> and won the [[Anita Borg Institute]]'s 2014 Social Impact [[ABIE award]],<ref name="Abie">{{cite web|url=https://anitab.org/profiles/abie-award-winners/ruthe-farmer/ |title=2014 Winner of the Grace Hopper Celebration Social Impact ABIE Award |publisher=[[Anita Borg Institute]]}}</ref> and was named among the "Forty Over 40 Women to Watch in America" in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortyover40.com/2015-honorees/ |title=2015 Honorees |publisher=Forty Over 40}}</ref> Between 2016 through the end of the Obama administration in January 2017, Farmer was the Senior Policy Advisor for Tech Inclusion at the [[White House Office of Science and Technology Policy]] with a focus on implementing the Obama administration's CS for All initiative with an emphasis on including under-represented groups.<ref name="LinkedIn"/> She now (2018) serves as the Chief Evangelist for the [[CSforAll Consortium]].
==References== <references />
==External links== * {{cite web|url=https://www.techrepublic.com/article/ruthe-farmer-ncwit-strategist-computer-science-advocate-tech-dumbledore/ |title=Ruthe Farmer: NCWIT strategist. Computer science advocate. Tech Dumbledore. |last=Gilpin |first=Lyndsey |date=2014-10-21 |publisher=TechRepublic}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Farmer, Ruthe}} [[Category:American nonprofit executives]] [[Category:Women nonprofit executives]] [[Category:Women in computing]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Computer science educators]] [[Category:Lewis & Clark College alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Saïd Business School]]

The '''Swiss Study Foundation''' (German "Schweizerische Studienstiftung", French "Fondation suisse d'études") is a foundation that promotes outstanding students (top 0.3%) during their undergraduate and postgraduate studies. Requirements for admission are outstanding intellectual interests and capabilities, creativity, and character.
The Swiss Study Foundation was founded 1991 in analogy to the [[Studienstiftung des deutschen Volkes]], its German equivalent. Currently, about 750 students are in the programme.
==Notable alumni== * [[Caroline Jaden Stussi]], actress * [[Balthasar Glättli]], politician * [[Oliver Schmitt]], historian
==See also== * [[Studienstiftung des deutschen Volkes]] * [[National Merit Scholarship Program]]
==External links== * http://www.studienstiftung.ch

{{distinguish|South Pacific Association of Theological Schools}} The '''South Pacific Association of Evangelical Colleges''' (SPAEC) (previously the '''South Pacific Association of Bible Colleges''' (SPABC)) is an association of independent evangelical Bible Colleges. It was formed in 1969. Colleges are located in [[Australia]] (all states plus the [[Australian Capital Territory]]), [[Papua New Guinea]], [[Vanuatu]] and [[New Zealand]].
Membership "requires agreement with the Association’s evangelical position with regard to God, Jesus, the Holy Spirit, salvation and the Bible", and is conditional on meeting standards [https://web.archive.org/web/20021011035710/http://www.spabc.com.au/] relating to: *"Stability of operation. *Leadership and administration. *Financial responsibility. *Number and qualifications of full-time faculty. *Relationship to the Christian community at large. *Resources — human and physical - supporting the programs. *Attention to Christian character development in students."
Member colleges are regularly reassessed to assure that the standards are maintained.
==Current members== *[[Adelaide College of Ministries]] *[[Bible College of South Australia]] (formerly Adelaide Bible Institute) *Booth College (NSW) (formerly The Salvation Army College of Further Education) *[[Brisbane School of Theology]] (formerly Crossway College, Bible College of Queensland and Queensland Bible Institute) *[[Torchbearers International|Capernwray Torchbearers Australia]] *[[Carey Baptist College]] (offers distance education) *[[Christian Leaders Training College]] (also offers distance education) *[[Emmaus Bible College, Australia|Emmaus Bible College]] (offers distance education) *[[Laidlaw College]] (formerly Bible College of New Zealand) *[[Malyon College]] - Queensland Baptist College of Ministries (offers distance education) *[[Melbourne School of Theology]] (formerly Bible College of Victoria) *[[Morling College]] (offers distance education) *[[Nazarene Theological College (Australia)|Nazarene Theological College]] *[[Pathways College of Bible and Mission]] (offers distance education) *[[Perth Bible College]] *[[Reformed Theological College]] (offers distance education) *[[Sydney Missionary and Bible College]] (offers distance education) *[[Tabor College Victoria]] *[[Tabor College Australia|Tabor College Perth]] (offers distance education) *[[Talua Ministry Training Centre]] *[[World View Centre for Intercultural Studies]]
==Previous members== *[[Alliance College of Australia]] (formerly Canberra College of Theology) *[[Bible College of Western Australia]] (formerly West Australian Bible College) *[[Dunamis International College of Ministries]] *[[Harvest Bible College]] *[[Kingsley College, Melbourne|Kingsley College]] *[[New Covenant International Bible College]] *[[Tahlee Bible College]]
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.spaec.org/}}

'''Stand up for us''' is the policy to combat [[homophobia]] in [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[junior school|junior]] and [[secondary school|secondary]] schools, published jointly by the [[Department for Children, Schools and Families]] and the [[British Department of Health|Department of Health]]. Schools which implement the policy are helping to meet requirements of the [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2004/31/contents Children Act 2004] which aims to improve every child's:--
(a) physical and mental health and emotional well-being
(b) protection from harm and neglect
(c) education, training and recreation
(d) contribution made to society
(e) social and economic well-being
These are the five outcomes for children identified in the [[green paper]] upon which the Act is based.<ref>http://www.everychildmatters.gov.uk/deliveringservices/multiagencyworking/glossary/?asset=glossary&id=22828</ref>
''Stand up for us'' was first announced as part of [[anti-bullying week]] in November 2004.<ref>[http://www.nice.org.uk/aboutnice/whoweare/aboutthehda/hdapublications/stand_up_for_us_challenging_homophobia_in_schools.jsp ''Stand up for us'']</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nice.org.uk/niceMedia/documents/stand_up_for_us.pdf Stand up for us] SUFU pdf file * [http://www.anti-bullyingalliance.org/ Anti-Bullying Alliance (ABA)] * [http://www.eachaction.org.uk/ Educational Action Challenging Homophobia (EACH)]

[[File:Loft Literary Center lobby at Open Book, Minneapolis, August 2012.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the Loft in Open Book's Cowles Literary Commons]] {{ad|date=June 2016}} '''The Loft Literary Center''' is a nonprofit literary organization located in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] incorporated in 1975.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: About the Loft |url=https://www.loft.org/about/}}</ref> The Loft is one of the nation’s largest and most comprehensive independent literary centers, and offers a variety of writing classes, conferences, grants, readings, writers' studios and other services to both established and emerging writers.<ref>{{cite web| title=The New York Times: With Books as a Catalyst, Minneapolis Neighborhood Revives |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/30/realestate/commercial/30books.html?_r=3&oref=slogin&}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: Resources |url=https://www.loft.org/resources/}}</ref>
Each year the Loft hosts more than 400 writers and performers that draw more than 12,000 people, and collaborates with at least 30 local and national organizations. The Loft additionally claims to have more than 170,000 unique visitors through digital resources and online writing classes.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: Annual Report |url=https://www.loft.org/about/annual_report/}}</ref>
==History==
===Inception===
Incorporated in 1975, the Loft started in a bookstore when a group of writers decided to offer classes and readings in the upstairs loft. Following a series of successful events held at Rusoff & Co. Book Dealers in [[Dinkytown]], Minnesota, bookstore owner Marly Rusoff and writers Jim Moore, [[Patricia Hampl]], Phebe Hanson, and Michael Dennis Browne formed a ‘poets’ club’ with support from a fundraising party emceed by [[Garrison Keillor]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Altered Scale: Rebecca Weaver on The Loft in the 70s |url=http://alteredscale.com/contentsandnavigation/rebecca-weaver-on-the-loft/}}</ref> This ‘poets’ club’ eventually became known as ‘The Loft,’ and in 1975 filed for nonprofit status and received a grant from the Minnesota State Arts Board to sponsor several writing workshops.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Pioneer Press: Marly Rusoff: St. Paul native, Loft 'mother,' literary agent and now publisher |url=http://www.twincities.com/entertainment/ci_23974915/loft-mother-and-literary-agent-rusoff-is-now}}</ref> Over the next two years, the Loft hosted a number of benefit readings that featured poets such as [[Allen Ginsberg]], [[Robert Bly]], and [[Etheridge Knight]].<ref>{{cite web| title=The Minnesota Historical Society: Loft Literary Center |url=http://www2.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00213.xml}}</ref>
===Continued growth===
Over the years, the Loft grew organically as a community-based nonprofit to become one of the nation’s leading independent literary centers.<ref>{{cite web| title=Minnesota Women's Press: A Home for Writers |url=http://www.womenspress.com/print.asp?ArticleID=2327&SectionID=1&SubSectionID=1}}</ref> With support from the Jerome Foundation the Loft launched the Mentor Series in 1980, bringing together nationally prominent authors with promising local writers.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Jerome Foundation: The Loft Literary Center |url=http://www.jeromefdn.org/grantees/2008-loft-literary-center-mentor-series}}</ref> The first year featured New York Times bestselling author [[Marge Piercy]] and Pulitzer Prize-winning poets [[Philip Levine (poet)|Philip Levine]] and [[Galway Kinnell]]. Other programs launched in the organization’s first decade include the McKnight Artist Fellowship in Creative Writing (1982), The Loft Scholarship Fund (1984), and a radio program in collaboration with [[Minnesota Public Radio]] (1985).<ref>{{cite web| title=The McKnight Foundation: McKnight honors artists selected for fellowships and residencies in 30th year of fellowships program |url=http://www.mcknight.org/newsroom/news-releases/mcknight-honors-artists-selected-for-fellowships-and-residencies-in-30th-year-of-fellowships-program}}</ref> In 1990, Loft membership passed the 2,000 mark, and in 1996 the Loft awarded more than $160,000 in grants to writers.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: History |url=https://www.loft.org/about/history/}}</ref>
===Social engagement===
The Loft initiated the Amnesty Action Project in 1988, which coordinated letter-writing campaigns on behalf of imprisoned writers as identified by [[Amnesty International]].<ref>{{cite web| title=The Minnesota Historical Society: Loft Literary Center |url=http://www2.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00213.xml}}</ref> Prominent Malawian poet [[Jack Mapanje]] was the first, followed by political prisoners Jaki Seroke, [[Zwelakhe Sisulu]], [[Nguyễn Chí Thiện]], [[Dai Qing]], Lee San-ha, and Bligesu Erenus.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Minnesota Historical Society: Loft Literary Center |url=http://www2.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00213.xml}}</ref> The following year, WCCO anchor [[Dave Moore (newscaster)|Dave Moore]] read from [[Salman Rushdie]]’s Satanic Verses at the Loft in protest of [[Ayatollah Khomeini]]’s sentence of death on Rushdie. The reading was also a response from the Twin Cities Artistic Community Ad Hoc Committee in Protest of Censorship and Intimidation.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: History |url=https://www.loft.org/about/history/}}</ref> In 1993, the Loft hosted a week-long series of events celebrating freedom of expression that coincided with National Banned Books Week. The events included a dialogue with [[Kathy Acker]], [[Amiri Baraka]], and [[Nat Hentoff]]; a reading and forum with [[Lorrie Moore]] and [[Mona Simpson]]; free speech read-ins; and performance art with J. Otis Powell and Patrick Scully at the Rogue Nightclub.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: History |url=https://www.loft.org/about/history/}}</ref>
===2000-present===
In 1999, the Loft joined forces with [[Minnesota Center for Book Arts]] and publisher [[Milkweed Editions]] to build the nonprofit literary and book arts center [[Open Book Minneapolis|Open Book]], which opened in May 2000 and is the current home of the Loft.<ref>{{cite news| title=With Books as a Catalyst, Minneapolis Neighborhood Revives|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/30/realestate/commercial/30books.html|accessdate=2009-03-27 | work=The New York Times | first=Lisa | last=Chamberlain | date=2008-04-30}}</ref> This move was followed by the launch of the Loft Equilibrium Spoken Word Series in 2002, which was recognized with the Minnesota Nonprofit Anti-Racism Initiative Award.<ref>{{cite web| title=Star Tribune:The Loft Literary Center awarded $150,000 grant for spoken word|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/blogs/152329425.html}}</ref> In 2004, the Loft hosted a reading by former senator and anti-war presidential candidate [[Eugene McCarthy]], and collaborated with the [[Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs]] and [[Minnesota International Center]] to host a discussion and book signing by former Secretary of State [[Madeleine Albright]].<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: History |url=https://www.loft.org/about/history/}}</ref>
In 2010, the Loft celebrated its 35th anniversary with the publication release of ''Views from the Loft: A Portable Writer's Workshop'' and the launch of its online education program.<ref>{{cite web| title=Publishers Weekly: Views from the Loft: A Portable Writer's Workshop|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-57131-323-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: History |url=https://www.loft.org/about/history/}}</ref>
The Loft now has an annual budget of over $2.4 million, and through contracts, awards, and grants pays writers more than $400,000 each year. The Loft annually serves thousands of writers by offering hundreds of classes, numerous fellowships, readings from award-winning authors, and literary resources such as a small library, writing studios, and a book club room.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: Resources |url=https://www.loft.org/resources/}}</ref> In 2013, the Loft hired 227 writers to teach 323 classes and 5 conferences. In their evaluations, 96% of students reported that their class helped them improve their writing, 91% identified their next steps as a writer, and 94% would recommend their class to others.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center: Annual Report |url=https://www.loft.org/about/annual_report/}}</ref>
Jocelyn Hale has been Executive Director since 2007, when she replaced long-time leader Linda Myers.<ref>{{cite web| title=Loft Literary Center names new director |url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2007/07/20/loftdirector/|accessdate=2014-09-25}}</ref>
===Programs===
*Online and in-person writing classes for youth and adult students<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Classes|url=https://www.loft.org/classes/}}</ref> *First Pages Labs, offered in collaboration with [[Hennepin County Library]]<ref>{{cite web| title=Programming Librarian:Interactive Programs at Hennepin County Library|url=http://www.programminglibrarian.org/january-2012/interactive-programs-hennepin-county-library#.U3JDJ-IlqSo}}</ref> *Manuscript Critique and Coaching<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Manuscript Critique and Coaching|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/educational_programs/manuscript_critique/}}</ref> *Children’s and Young Adult Literature Conference<ref>{{cite web| title=Association of Writers & Writing Programs:The Loft Literary Center|url=https://www.awpwriter.org/programs_conferences/wcc_entry_view/614/loft_literary_center_the}}</ref> *Master Mondays Advanced Classes<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Master Mondays|url=https://writersblock.loft.org/2013/12/09/2883/master_mondays_an_interview_with_david_mura}}</ref> *School-Based Teaching Artist in Residence Program<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Teaching Artist in Residence Program|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/educational_programs/residency_program/}}</ref> *Professional Development Residencies<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Professional Development Residencies|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/educational_programs/residency_program/professional_development_residencies/}}</ref> *Residencies in Partnership with Human Service Organizations<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Residencies in Partnership with Human Service Organizations|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/educational_programs/residency_program/human_service_residencies/}}</ref> *Minnesota's [[Poetry Out Loud]] Competition<ref>{{cite web| title=Minnesota State Arts Board:Poetry Out Loud|url=http://www.arts.state.mn.us/other/poetry.htm}}</ref>
===Events===
*Talking Volumes, a partnership of the [[Star Tribune]] and [[Minnesota Public Radio]], in collaboration with the Loft.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Wallace Foundation:Talking Volumes|url=http://www.wallacefoundation.org/knowledge-center/audience-development-for-the-arts/strategies-for-expanding-audiences/Pages/The-Loft-Literary-Center-Talking-Volumes.aspx}}</ref> *Loft Mentor Series Readings<ref>{{cite web| title=The Jerome Foundation:The Loft Literary Center Loft Mentor Series|url=http://www.jeromefdn.org/node/566669}}</ref> *McKnight Artist Fellowship Readings<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:McKnight Artist Fellowship Readings|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/readings__events/mcknight_series/}}</ref> *Publication Readings at the Loft<ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Publication Readings at the Loft|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/readings__events/publication_readings/}}</ref> *Equilibrium: Spoken Word Series, which features writers of color and was named the 2010 Minnesota Nonprofit Award Winner for Anti-Racism Initiative<ref>{{cite web| title=Minnesota Public Radio:Loft Literary Center Wins Major Grant for its Spoken Word Program|url=http://blogs.mprnews.org/state-of-the-arts/2012/05/loft-literary-center/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=Minnesota Council of Nonprofts:Nonprofit Awards|url=http://www.minnesotanonprofits.org/mission-excellence-awards/past-recipients-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=Star Tribune:The Loft Literary Center awarded $150,000 grant for spoken word|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/blogs/152329425.html}}</ref> *Second Story Reading Series for young adult, middle-grade, and picture book authors<ref>{{cite web| title=H.M. Bouwman:Second Story Reading Series|url=http://www.hmbouwman.com/second-story-reading-series.html}}</ref>
===Grants, Awards, and Fellowships===
*McKnight Artist Fellowships for Writers<ref>{{cite web| title=McKnight Foundation:McKnight Artist Fellowships Program|url=http://www.mcknight.org/grant-programs/arts/artist-fellowships}}</ref> *The Loft Mentor Series<ref>{{cite web| title=PEN American:Loft Literary Center Mentor Series Contest|url=http://www.pen.org/grants-and-awards/loft-literary-center-mentor-series-contest}}</ref> *Minnesota Emerging Writers’ Grant<ref>{{cite web| title=Poets & Writers:Loft Literary Center Minnesota Emerging Writers’ Grant|url=http://www.pw.org/writing_contests/minnesota_emerging_writers_grant}}</ref> *The Loft Spoken Word Immersion Fellowship<ref>{{cite web| title=Asian American Press:Loft Spoken Word Immersion Fellows|url=http://aapress.com/category/arts/spoken-word/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:The Loft Spoken Word Immersion Fellowship|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/grants__awards/spoken_word_grant/}}</ref> *The Loft Inroads Mentoring Award<ref>{{cite web| title=Knight Arts:Twin Cities writers from immigrant and refugee communities make "Inroads" at the Black Dog|url=http://www.knightarts.org/community/stpaul/twin-cities-writers-from-immigrant-and-refugee-communities-make-inroads-at-the-black-dog}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Loft Inroads Mentoring Award|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/grants__awards/inroads_award/}}</ref> *Excellence in Teaching Fellowships, in collaboration with Madeline Island School for the Arts<ref>{{cite web| title=Madeline Island School for the Arts:Excellence in Teaching Fellowships|url=https://secure.madelineartschool.com/Writing_Fellowships.cfm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=The Loft Literary Center:Excellence in Teaching Fellowships|url=https://www.loft.org/programs__awards/grants__awards/excellence_in_teaching/}}</ref>
==Influential Collaborators==
Thousands of writers both established and emerging have read, taught, mentored, and judged contests at the Loft since 1975. Their ranks include [[Margaret Atwood]], [[Charles Baxter (author)|Charles Baxter]], [[Robert Bly]], [[Billy Collins]], [[Bernard Cooper]], [[Toi Derricotte]], [[Junot Diaz]], [[Kate DiCamillo]], [[Rita Dove]], [[Louise Erdrich]], [[Vince Flynn]], [[Nikki Giovanni]], [[Patricia Hampl]], [[John Irving]], [[Garrison Keillor]], [[Stanley Kunitz]], [[Mary Oliver]], [[Michael Ondaatje]], [[Tracy K. Smith]], [[Patricia Smith (poet)|Patricia Smith]], [[Quincy Troupe]], and [[Li-Young Lee]], among others.
==Records== Records of the Loft Literary Center are housed at the [[Minnesota Historical Society]] and available for research use. They include bylaws and statement of purpose, minutes, correspondence, financial information, annual reports, information on classes and readings, class proposals, and membership data, among other files.<ref>[http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00213.xml Records of the Loft]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.loft.org The Loft Literary Center]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Loft Literary Center, The}} [[Category:Creative writing programs]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Minnesota]] [[Category:Arts organizations in Minneapolis]]
